coredata.dc:title: Advanced electrolyte design for stable lithium metal anode: From liquid to solid
coredata.dc:creator: Wang, Qian
Wang, Hangchao
Wu, Jianyang
Zhou, Mingyue
Liu, Wen
Zhou, Henghui
coredata.dc:description: Li metal anode is among the most promising anode materials for next generation of lithium batteries (Li–O2, Li–S batteries). However, the commercial applications of Li metal batteries have been seriously hindered due to safety and lifetime concerns caused by the formation of Li dendrites. In this review, we focus on the electrolyte designs in handling Li dendritic growth and improving electrochemical performance of Li metal anode, and outline the trend of electrolyte designs from traditional composition adjustment of the liquid electrolyte to molecular design of the solid polymer electrolyte. We aim to provide strategic guidance for the rational design and fabrication of safety electrolytes, and to explore the possibility of these designs in practical application. We critically evaluate the existing challenges and future opportunities associated with this burgeoning field.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Li metal anode is among the most promising anode materials for next generation of lithium batteries (Li–O2, Li–S batteries). However, the commercial applications of Li metal batteries have been seriously hindered due to safety and lifetime concerns caused by the formation of Li dendrites. In this review, we focus on the electrolyte designs in handling Li dendritic growth and improving electrochemical performance of Li metal anode, and outline the trend of electrolyte designs from traditional composition adjustment of the liquid electrolyte to molecular design of the solid polymer electrolyte. We aim to provide strategic guidance for the rational design and fabrication of safety electrolytes, and to explore the possibility of these designs in practical application. We critically evaluate the existing challenges and future opportunities associated with this burgeoning field.

ce:section.ce:para: Since its commercialization in 1991, Li-ions batteries have been widely used in all aspects of human life, such as electric vehicles, portable electronics, and grid energy storage stations [1–5]. However, traditional Li-ions batteries (LIBs) based on graphite anode are hardly to satisfy the growing demand for high energy density [6–8]. It is extremely urgent to develop novel battery chemistry, and it is now widely accepted that Li metal batteries (LMBs) using Li metal as anode are promising to address the anxiety about energy density [9–11].

Li metal has been considered as the “Holy Grail” among all anode materials because of its high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mA h g−1), low density (0.59 g cm−3) and the lowest electrochemical potential (−3.040 V vs SHE (standard hydrogen electrode)) [12–16]. Furthermore, when Li metal anode is paired with different cathode materials, such as typical LiFePO4, LiCoO2, LiNixCoyMn1−x−yO2 cathodes even S, O2 cathodes, different types of LIBs with improved energy density and potential can be obtained [17–22]. Notably, Li–S batteries based on Li metal anode display an extremely high theoretical energy density (2600 W h kg−1) [23–25]. Beyond that, the low-cost and environmental-friendly natures of S cathode make Li–-S batteries a promising candidate for the next-generation rechargeable LIBs (
Fig. 1a and b) [26,27]. Return to reality, if using Li metal anode, it is also very hopeful for LIBs to approach the energy density 500 W h kg−1 in the next 5–10 years according to the future development trends of energy density (Fig. 1c and d) [28,29], which means that the electric vehicles can finally overcome petrol vehicles in future market. In a nutshell, it seems an inevitable choice to use Li meal anode in the future market.

In fact, Li metal anode has been attempted to use in Li-ion batteries research in the 1970s [30–33]. However, the serious safety risks restricted its further development. After 2010s, the fast growing market demands for energy density led to world-wide research surge in Li metal anode for next-generation rechargeable LMBs. The relevant publications also exhibited exponential increase since 2010s (Fig. 1e). Up to now, there are several critical issues for Li metal anode [34–39]: a) Li metal has very high chemical and electrochemical reactivity, means it can react with almost all electrolytes, which will result in the corrosion and low utilization rate of Li metal. b) during the continuous Li plating process, an uneven Li+ flux distribution near electrode surface will cause the uneven Li deposition due to the existence of local space charge layer, thus producing dendritic Li metal. Dendritic Li maybe pierce the separator and cause a series of security problems, such as internal short circuit, thermal runaway, fire, and explosion. Besides, dendritic Li breaks easily from the roots leading the loss of active Li (so-called “dead Li”). c) Li metal anode suffers from huge volume expansion and contraction during long-term Li plating/stripping process, leading to continuous reconfiguration of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer, which lowers the coulombic efficiency (CE) and cycle life.

In the past decade, a lot of efforts have been devoted to address the above mentioned problems, including coating an artificial physical/chemical protective layer on the surface of Li metal electrode via atomic layer deposition (ALD) [40], spin coating [41], hard template [42] and other strategies; optimizing the SEI and doping inorganic components to improve its mechanical strength and lithophilicity, such as Li3N [43–46], Li3PO4 [47,48], LiF [49–52], Li2S [53–56]; constructing conductive 3D framework to buffer the volume change and suppress the growth of dendritic Li [57–63]; regulating the electrolyte composition and introducing additives [64–67]; inducing uniform nucleation and growth of Li metal by metal/metal-oxide nanoparticles [68–71]; employing solid-state electrolyte with high strength to block the dendrite propagation [72–76].

Among these approaches, electrolyte design has been attracting more and more attention, because electrolyte is one of the most critical parts of LMBs, undertaking the heavy responsibility of Li+ transport, which directly affects the electrochemical performance of LMBs [77–82]. Although ether-based and ester-based electrolytes have been commercialized in traditional Li-ions batteries for many years, for Li metal batteries, they both face huge challenge, especially in columbic efficiency and safety. In brief, advanced electrolyte design shows great potential for stable Li metal anode but still has certain distance from practical applications in LMBs. How to design efficient electrolytes is becoming an interdisciplinary science with both challenges and opportunities for researchers to exploit endless.

It is necessary to organize a critical review regarding the electrolyte design for Li metal batteries to provide a comprehensive understanding and serve as a strategic guidance for rational design of advanced electrolyte in the future. However, most existing reviews on similar topics focus on the summary of one or several strategies, such as a summary of additives, a summary of high-concentrated electrolytes and even a review of nonflammable electrolyte, et al., ignoring their internal connection and the evolution process in practical application, failing to provide the readers with a comprehensive overview about the nature of the problems and development trend of electrolyte design toward LMBs. For overcoming these limitations, we organize this review based the electrolyte design of Li metal anode to look for possible approaches and obtain improved electrochemical performance and high safety. We illustrated the formation and growth mechanism of dendritic Li, meanwhile, outlined the recent advances in electrolyte design from liquid to solid. Finally, we evaluate the current challenges and future possibilities of electrolyte in LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The formation mechanism of Li dendrites and related issues

ce:section.ce:para: Until now, several models have been proposed to describe Li dendrites formation and growth ( Table 1). Although these models can not completely describe the nucleation and growth behavior of Li metal, we still can use them to understand the electrochemical behavior of Li metal in LMBs.

The space-charge model was proposed by Chazalviel in 1990 and has become the most accepted theory for explaining the initial nucleation process [83]. In dilute solution, the model confirmed that the Li dendritic formation was caused by space-charge layer on the solution surface. As shown in Fig. 2a and b, in a thin rectangular cell filled with dilute solution, when the metal cation was reduced to metal, the cell can be divided into two regions: region 1 (the quasineutral region) and region 2 (the space-charge region). Region 2 is closed to the electrode surface and the ions transfer is mainly controlled by surface diffusion. Then, dendrites would be formed after the metal cation concentration on the electrode surface decreasing to 0. However, if using high-concentration electrolyte or improving the transference number of metal cation, the thickness of the space charge layer will become thin. Thus, improving transference number of Li+, using high-concentration electrolyte and plating at low current density can suppress the Li dendrites formation effectively.

The space-charge model has its limitations for explaining the formation of Li dendrites, because it doesn't take into account the reaction between Li metal and electrolyte. Li metal can react with organic electrolyte to form a SEI on its surface because of its high chemical reactivity. However, because the spontaneously formed SEI is porous, the Li+ concentration can be enriched near the holes, means an uneven distribution of Li-ion flux, which leads to rapid Li plating and dendritic growth. Besides, during subsequent charging–discharging process, the SEI layer can not effectively buffer the large volumetric expansion of Li electrode due to its poor mechanical strength and partially soluble property, resulting in a lot of cracks on the SEI surface. These cracks expose fresh Li metal, in which the electric field and charge density is higher. Then, Li-ions prefer to be reduced and deposited on these naked fresh Li metal protrusions, which leading to rapid growth of Li dendrite and new SEI formation (Fig. 2c) [84]. The continuous dendrites growth and recurring SEI formation will lead to a thick accumulated SEI layer and porous Li electrode, which blocks the Li+ transfer and causes capacity fading. Thus, it is a very effective strategy for suppressing dendritic growth to stabilize and strengthen SEI layer.

The heterogeneous nucleation model is mainly used to explain the effect of initial nucleation on Li deposition. Ely et al. divided the nucleation behavior into five regimes [85]: a nucleation suppression regime, a long incubation time regime, a short incubation regime, an early growth regime, and a late growth regime. A stable electrodeposited nucleus needs the size of embryo to be bigger than thermodynamic and kinetic critical radius, if not, the embryo may dissolve into the electrolyte again. Once the size of embryo exceeds critical radius after overcoming the critical energy barrier, it will grow under the fluctuation of electric field and ionic field. Then, in early growth regime and late growth regime, the nucleus will grow to terminal size gradually (Fig. 2d–f). Thus, controlling the initial Li nucleation process is extremely helpful for suppressing even avoiding dendritic growth.

Based on this theory, Cui Group compared the nucleation process of Li+ on various substrates (such as: Pt, Al, Mg, Zn, Ag, Au, C, Sn, Si et al.). They demonstrated Li deposition on Au substrate without over-potential. Meantime, after introducing Au nanoseeds into carbon nanoshells, the Li can deposit and grow in the inside of hollow carbon sphere and a smooth carbon sphere surface without Li dendrites can be observed (Fig. 2g–i) [86].

The growth of Li dendrites during repeated charging and discharging cycles is the main reason to hinder the commercial application of LMBs. It will cause several obstacles as follows ( Fig. 3a): a) internal short circuit even short circuit. Dendritic Li can penetrate through the separator and touch with cathode, causing internal micro short circuit. As the phenomenon continuing, it could cause severe short circuit, accompanying by thermal runaway, fire, and even explosion [87]. b) the formation of “dead Li”. The “dead Li” is mainly formed in Li stripping process. As shown in Fig. 3b, firstly, the Li dissolves from the tips and kink points, and then strips from the substrate. If the dissolution current is smaller than the deposition current, only a smaller amount of Li metal can be stripped from the tips and kink points, Li whiskers could be stripped from the roots of Li metal and become “dead Li”, thus leading to the loss of Li and low CE [88]. c) high surface and huge volume change. The formation of Li dendrites causes the Li deposition is more porous, resulting in increased specific surface area and high volume change. Besides, because of its hostless property, the Li metal behaviors a more and more volume expansion during long-term Li plating/stripping process, which is a huge challenge for SEI stability. d) Increased polarization. The formation of Li dendrites leads to a porous and uneven structure composing numerous “dead Li”, which increases diffusion pathway and huge resistance of Li ions and electrons, in this way rendering a large polarization. In short, Li dendrites not only cause battery failure but also are the main reason for low CE and poor cycling stability [89–91].

As an important component of LIBs, electrolyte plays a key role in transferring ions. It affects the specific energy, safety, cycling performance, rate-performance and cost of LIBs. At present, the common electrolyte is composed of Li salts and organic solvents. The optimization of electrolyte system has attracted wide attention. For an idea electrolyte for LMBs, it should have following properties: a) high ionic conductivity and low electronic conductivity; b) wide electrochemical window and low viscosity; c) high thermal stability and wider operation temperature range; d) high chemical stability, ensuring it doesn’t react with current collector and electrode materials; e) safe, low-cost and non-toxic. In this section, we’ll try to recall the advanced liquid electrolyte designs in Li metal anode.

Li metal surface always forms a SEI layer due to the decomposition of electrolyte components and subsequent deposition of these components [92–95]. The organic components in SEI layer are derived from solvent decomposition. As a solvent for Li salts, a high solubility of Li salts is essential, meanwhile, the solvent should also have high electrochemical stability, low viscosity, low melting temperature (Tm), high boiling temperature (Tb), high flash point (Tf), high Li+ diffusion coefficients and transference number, as well as low cost, etc. Take these factors into consideration, ester and ether solvents have been widely applied for LMBs. For example, in 2003, Zhang et al. systematically compared the surface topography of Li deposition in the electrolytes of 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in different solvents [96]. As shown in Fig. 4a, when using ethylene carbonate (EC) and polycarbonate (PC) as solvents, although the Li showed an uneven surface with a lot of protrusions, the morphology is more uniform than that in linear carbonate solvents (dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC)). Fig. 4b exhibited the surface morphologies of Li electrode after depositing the electrolytes containing EC, vinylene carbonate (VC), fluorethylene carbonate (FEC) and 4-vinyl-1,3-dioxlan-2-one (VEC) solvents with 1 M LiPF6 salt. Using VC solvents, the surface of Li metal was smooth and no dendrites were found. Maybe because the VC is polymerized on the electrode surface, which improves the mechanical strength of SEI layer. Meantime, the CE of Li metal anode in cyclic carbonate electrolytes (PC and EC) was higher than that in linear carbonates (DMC and EMC). Because these solvents (VC, FEC and VEC) are usually used as SEI-forming agents, the Li metal anode cycling in these three solvents exhibited high CE ( Table 2). Speaking of the SEI layer, in recent years, LiF can often be detected as a solid deposit on the surface of the electrodes, meanwhile, more and more researchers agree that the high content of LiF in SEI layer is beneficial to suppress the growth of Li dendrites. In solvent selection, if replacing the hydrogen atom with fluorine, some unique physicochemical properties would be displayed because of the low polarizability and high electronegativity of F atom, such as: increased anodic stability, decreased cathodic stability and even noninflammability [97,98]. As shown in Table 3, compared with EC solvent, with the increase of fluorination degree, the Tm, Tb, Tf and the dielectric constant decreases due to the introduce of electron-withdrawing F atoms, which induces an elevated chemical polarity and a decrease in the intermolecular interactions. However, owing to the steric hindrance, FEC exhibits a high viscosity and increased density. In linear carbonate solvent (DEC), as the degree of fluorination increases, the Tm value increases, whereas the Tf value and the density decrease, whereas the viscosity increases because of a bulky side chain. As a consequence of the increased viscosity and the reduced solvation ability of the fluorinated carbonate solvent, the ionic conductivity is decreased and decreases as the degree of fluorination increases. In addition, some reports suggest that the increased degree of fluorination can reduce aluminum dissolution [99].

Up to now, FEC is the most widely used. In Si anode, Lucht et al. found that using FEC instead of EC as a single solvent can improve the cycling stability of Si anode because of the formation of an effective SEI [100]. Furthermore, FEC can be blended with ester solvents. The FEC-containing electrolyte forms a dense and thick SEI layer, which consists mainly of LiF. Brezesinski Group reported that replacing the EC with FEC, the ethylene gas product was not detected during prolonged cycling [101]. However, it is not clear why different gas products are formed in FEC-containing electrolyte and EC-containing electrolyte. In the Li metal anode, the use of FEC can lead to an improved lithium plating/stripping behavior because of diminished electrolyte decomposition, as observed in SEM analysis [102]. Furthermore, this leads to an extended cycling stability in NCM622 | Li full cells (Fig. 4e).

Briefly, in solvent selection, replacing the H atom with F is an effective strategy to obtain stable SEI layer. Even some Groups have attempted to develop full-fluoride solvents (such as: both terminal carbon atoms are fully fluorinated) to improve the cycling performance of Li metal anode. These scientific results are a good starting point to evaluate the impact of F replacing. However, the effect of various degrees of fluorination on the physical and chemical properties of organic cyclic and linear carbonate solvents is in many cases not clear, thus, the degree of fluorination must be chosen carefully according to the structure of solvent in further study [103].

Recently, aromatic solvents are also attempted to use in carbonate-based electrolyte as a co-solvent [104,105]. Choi et al. used toluene as a co-solvent in ester-based electrolyte [106]. The toluene can be decomposed prior to ester solvents, resulting in a more uniform and rigid SEI layer. With toluene as co-solvent, the Li metal electrode after Li deposition exhibited a more smooth surface morphology than that in base electrolyte. The -CH3 in toluene plays a key role in the precedented decomposition, leading to facile radical polymerization, meanwhile, the polymerization process of toluene can induce the uniform distribution of LiF. Thus, Li metal anode showed a high average CE of 97.2% over 350 cycles in ester-based electrolyte.

Beyond solvent itself, the solvent ratio also has an important effect on CE and cycling stability of LMBs. Zhang Group found that the CE of Li metal anode can be improved with the increase of EC amount in mixed solvent [107]. This is because that EC can be reduced to Li alkyl carbonates and then polymerized to form polycarbonates passivation film on the Li metal surface, which enhanced the mechanical strength of SEI layer to protect Li metal electrode (Fig. 4d). Ether solvents also exhibit similar results. However, when using ether solvents, the morphology of Li deposition is smoother than that in ester solvents. Furthermore, using the mixture of ester and ether solvents also can suppress dendritic formation and improve the CE of Li metal anode. Huang et al. reported an interesting phenomenon that Li dendrites can be self-inhibited in ester-ether mixed electrolyte [108]. As shown in Fig. 4c, when adding different concentrations 1,2-Dimethoxyethane (DME) into ester-based electrolyte, the surface morphology of Li electrode after 50 cycles changed drastically. The needle-like Li dendrites gradually disappeared from the electrode surface with increasing DME concentration in electrolyte. That is because the SEI layer using ester-ether mixed electrolyte contains a lot of LiF and ‒(CH2CH2O)‒, which have high chemical stability, high flexibility, helping to suppress the formation of Li dendrites.

Apart from solvents, Li salts are another important factor that affects the electrochemical performance of Li metal anode. An idea Li salt should satisfy these requirements: 1) good solubility; 2) high ionic conductivity; 3) high chemical stability; 4) wide electrochemical window; 5) high purity; 6) low molecular weight; 7) low toxicity; 8) high mobility of the solvated ions (especially solvated Li+ ions); 9) effective SEI and CEI formation; 10) low-cost. To date, a lot of Li salts have been reported, including lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6), lithium bis(oxalate)borate (LiBOB), lithium tetrafluoroborate (LiBF4), lithium bis(triﬂuoromethane sulfonimide) (LiTFSI), lithium hexafluoroarsenate (LiAsF6), lithium perchlorate (LiClO4), lithium trifluoromethanesulfonate (LiCF3SO3) et al. It can be seen that most of the common Li salts contain fluorinated anions. That is because the delocalized charge of the anion and electron-withdrawing properties of F atoms can ensure its high solubility in organic aprotic solvents [109]. The Li+ is defined as a hard Lewis acid because of its small ionic radius and high charge density. If combining with hard Lewis bases (such as: F−), it will lead to strong lattice energies and difficult ion separation, thereby reducing the ionic conductivity. Thus, some softer Lewis bases, such as: PF6 − and BF4 − have been developed to reduce the lattice energy with the hard Li+ and improve the solubility of Li salts. Table 4 shows the main physical and chemical properties of typical Li salts [110]. In selecting Li salts, except for solubility, some other properties should also be considered, such as: ion mobility, thermal stability, surface chemistry, molecular weight, passivation ability of Al current collector, ion-pair dissociation. Considering all these factors, LiPF6 is regarded as the “best” Li salts in ester-based electrolyte. In the ether-based electrolyte, Zhang et al. investigated the effect of Li salts on the surface morphology and CE of Li metal anode [111]. As shown in Fig. 5a, when using LiBOB as Li salt, the Li metal electrode showed the best surface morphology. However, Li deposited in the electrolytes containing LiDFOB, LiBF4, LiCF3SO3, and LiClO4 salts cannot cover the Cu substrate very well. Meanwhile, the Li metal anode exhibited the highest CE in electrolyte containing LiAsF6, it could come from the formation of AsF3 during 1st cycle, after which the AsF3 covers the electrode surface and prevents further side reactions ( Table 5). When depositing in the electrolytes containing LiBOB or LiDFOB, the Li metal anode also showed higher CEs than the CEs obtained in the electrolyte with other Li salts. Niu et al. studied the effects of common LiPF6, LiClO4, and LiTFSI Li salts on the performance of Li metal anode [112]. As shown in Fig. 5b, the metal surface becomes porous and rough after 100 cycles, and the Li electrode shows the smallest volume expansion when cycling in the electrolyte containing LiTFSI Li salt. Furthermore, they found that the LiTFSI has the best compatibility with DOL/DME electrolyte, in which the Li metal anode shows the highest cycling stability and optimal rate-performance.

In addition to common Li salts, there have been numerous attempts to develop new Li salts. For example, Peng et al. reported a novel Li salt of Li[(CF3SO2)(n-C4F9SO2)N] (LiTNFSI), they found that LiTNFSI can suppress dendritic growth and interfacial side reaction during cycling, thereby improving the overall reversibility of Li–O2 batteries [113]. As shown in Fig. 5c, the SEI layer formed in LiTNFSI-TEGDME electrolyte is more uniform, stable than that in LiTFSI–TEGDME electrolyte. The richer F-containing species in LiTNFSI-TEGDME electrolyte lead to the SEI layer has excellent flexible. Thus, the side reactions between Li metal anode and dissolved O2 are effectively suppressed in LiTNFSI-TEGDME electrolyte. Benefit from this, the Li–O2 batteries run in LiTNFSI-TEGDME electrolyte exhibited an improved reversibility with an O2 recovery efficiency up to 95.7%. Besides, some F-replaced Li salts based LiBOB have also been tried, such as: Lithium bis(fluoromalonato)borate (LiBFMB), lithium bis(2-methyl-2-fluoromalonato)borate (LiBMFMB) [114–116]. After replacing with F, these Li salts show a high oxidation stability and electrochemical performance.

In short, in selecting Li salts, just from the molecular level, Li salts with fluoroanions of superacids are essential, which ensures a high solubility in high permittivity solvents and dipolar aprotic solvents, thereby enhancing the Li+ conductivity of electrolyte. However, these Li salts with the formula LiMFn (M = P, B, As, Sb) in electrolyte will form a small number of F− and MFn−1, which leads to the formation of HF acid and LiF [117]. Besides, electrochemical stability should also be considered. Although fluorinated molecule generally has high electrochemical stability, more and more researchers are constantly looking for high-voltage cathode materials to pair with Li metal anode to improve the energy density of LMBs. The electrochemical window of LiPF6 can be up to 5.0 V, which is enough for now. However, in the long term, higher electrochemical stability is still worth studying. Li salts with the formula of Li[(FSO2)(RxSO2)N], the oxidative stability can be improved by increasing the length of Rx (Rx = F, CF3, C2F5, n-C4F9) [118]. Furthermore, operability and air-stability are also very beneficial in actual production. Lithium 4,5-dicyano-2-trifluoromethylimidazolide (LiTDI) is an example that can be stored in air, meanwhile, it can effectively prevent the dissolution of Al by inhibiting the active centers on the Al/Al2O3 surface [119,120]. Thus, the novel Li salts should be designed carefully to balance all the factors in further study.

Beyond Li salts itself, dual-salts electrolyte has also been attempted to use in LMBs. Nuli et al. reported a novel dual-salts electrolyte composed of Li[N(SO2F)2] and Li[N(SO2CF3)2]. In the dual-salts system, the LiFSI not only can provide high conductivity, but also dominates the interfacial behavior, meanwhile, LiTFSI acts as stabilizer and conducting agent [121]. As shown in Fig. 5d, the Li metal anode showed a high CE of 91.6% at first cycle, then the CE can maintain 99% during cycling process, which is much higher than the CEs in single salt LiTFSI/LiFSI electrolyte system. Furthermore, a dendrite-free Li deposition and low potential polarization can be maintained even at high current density.

ce:section.ce:section-title: High-concentration electrolytes and localized high-concentration electrolytes
ce:section.ce:para: Generally, the concentration of Li salt is controlled at 1.0 M for balancing the solubility, viscosity and Li+ conductivity. However, according to a literature report, using the electrolyte with high salt concentration is very helpful for improving the stability of Li metal anode [122–127]. Concentrated electrolytes can passivate Li metal anode without the aid of other organic carbonates and stabilize Al current collectors. More importantly, the Li+ conductivity is directly related to the salt–solvent combination [128–133]. For solvent selection, due to the decrease of activity of solvent molecules at high-concentration, some solvents which have poor interfacial stability, such as: carbonic esters, nitriles, sulfones, phosphate, etc., thus can be used as solvents in high-concentration electrolytes, thereby greatly broadening the selection range of electrolyte solvents. However, the upper limit of interfacial stability strongly depends on the intrinsic antioxidant capacity of solvent. In other words, increasing the electrolyte concentration can only improve the electrochemical window to a certain extent. Besides, when the concentration of Li salts in an electrolyte is raised, the number of charge carriers and the viscosity will increase, leading to the decrease of ion mobility. Thus, the ether-based solvents with low viscosity are widely used in the research of high-concentration electrolytes. However, because of its poor oxidation resistance, ether-based solvent is mainly suitable for the low-voltage cathode materials, such as: S, O2, LiFePO4. Although the electrochemical window can be increased to 4.3 V by adjusting the concentration of Li salts, some other solvents (carbonic ester, nitrile, phosphate, ionic liquids, etc.) can be explored to match with high-voltage cathode materials, such as: NCM cathode (4.5 V), LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode (5.0 V). As shown in Fig. 6a, acetonitrile (AN)-based or water-based electrolytes have higher Li+ conductivity than commercial LiPF6/EC:DMC electrolyte. Thus, there is considerable room to explore various salt–solvent combinations for developing highly conductive electrolyte [134]. Zhang Group found that the highly concentrated electrolytes can greatly improve CE and inhibit the formation of Li dendrites even at high current density [135]. As shown in Fig. 6b, the electrode surface after depositing in typical ester-based electrolyte exhibited a needle-like morphology. In contrast, when depositing in concentrated electrolytes, nodule-like structure with round-shaped edges can be observed on electrode surface. Furthermore, a dark gray Li surface was observed after depositing in ester-based electrolyte, indicating serious side reactions between electrolyte and deposited Li metal. However, in concentrated electrolytes, the deposited Li is silver white shiny, suggesting that the concentrated electrolytes are much more stable with Li metal. Benefit from this, Li metal anode can be cycled over 1000 cycles with a high CE of 98.4% at the current density of 4.0 mA cm−2 in the concentrated electrolytes. Chen et al. proposed a higher-concentrated electrolyte with 7 M Li salts, which was called “solvent-in-salt” (Fig. 6c). The “solvent-in-salt” electrolyte can suppress dendritic formation with following merits: a) the space charge layer created by TFSI depletion can be minimized due to the presence of large amount of anions, which avoids the growth of Li dendrites; b) the Li+ transference number in “solvent-in-salt” electrolyte is higher than traditional electrolyte, which reduces the concentration polarization near electrode and enables uniform Li deposition; c) the high viscosity of “solvent-in-salt” electrolyte limits anion migration near deposition area and possibly increases the stress of dendritic growth. Thus, the Li metal anode in “solvent-in-salt” electrolyte can maintain a dendrite-free Li deposition and smooth surface morphology during cycling. In contrast, an uneven Li deposition can be observed when cycling in common electrolyte (Fig. 6d). The Li–S batteries using “solvent-in-salt” electrolyte also exhibited improved capacity retention and cycling stability [136].

For selecting Li salts, the most important consideration is solubility and molecular weight. According to a simple calculation, if dissolving 5 mol/L Li salts in 10 mL solvents, it needs 7.6 g for LiPF6, 14.4 g for LiTFSI, 9.7 g for LiBOB, 9.4 g for LiFSI. Considering solubility, LiFSI and LiTFSI are widely used in high-concentration electrolytes. Recently, concentrated dual-salts or ternary-salts electrolytes have also been developed for LMBs. Zhou et al. reported a concentrated ternary-salts LiTFSI–LiNO3–LiFSI/ethers electrolyte for LMBs [137]. In the concentrated ternary-salts electrolyte, LiNO3 and LiFSI can help form stable Li2O-rich and LiF-rich SEI layers, and the LiTFSI can avoid the polymerization of electrolyte under high concentration. Thus, the Cu | Li cells can maintain a high CE of 99.1% with low over-potential for 450 cycles. However, the Li metal anode showed a poor cycling stability and low CE in dual-salts LiTFSI–LiNO3/ethers electrolyte with only Li2O-rich layer (Fig. 6e). Furthermore, when using only 0.5 ×excess Li metal, the CE in concentrated ternary-salts electrolyte can be reached to 99.4%. The full cells of LiFePO4 | Li demonstrated > 92% capacity retention after 500 cycles.

Although high-concentration electrolyte can improve the stability of Li metal anode, poor wetting capability and high cost hinder its practical applications [138]. To address these challenges, Zhang Group proposed a novel concept: localized high-concentration electrolyte (LHCE) [139,140]. The LHCE is obtained by diluting high-concentration electrolyte (HCE) with an “inert” diluent. The “inert” diluent can be miscible with solvent and Li+-solvent solvates in the HCE, but it doesn’t dissolve Li salts. Therefore, adding “inert” diluent doesn’t affect the Li salt-solvent structure in HCE, but it significantly reduces the total amount of Li salts in HCE. To put it simply, LHCE can be regarded as a mixture of HCE with “inert” diluent at the molecular level. An idea diluent should satisfy these requirements: 1) low dielectric constant and low complexing ability; 2) low viscosity and high wettability; 3) Li salts cannot be dissolved; 4) mutually soluble with solvents; 5) can help form a stable SEI; 6) low-cost; 7) noninflammability. So far, only a few diluents have been developed, including: hydrofluoroether (HFE), bis(2,2,2-triﬂuoroethyl) ether (BTFE), 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropyl ether (TTE), hexafluoroisopropyl methyl ether (HFME), 1H,1H,5H-octafluoropentyl-1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl ether (OFE) and dichloromethane (DCM) [141]. They Group prepared a novel LHCE by diluting 5.5 M LiFSI/DMC with bis(2,2,2-triﬂuoroethyl) ether (BTFE) [142]. They found that the Li metal anode exhibited an improved CE when cycled in HCE (5.5 M LiFSI/DMC) than in dilute electrolyte (1.2 M LiFSI/DMC). However, the Li metal anode cycled in LHCE with reduced LiFSI concentration (1.2 M) demonstrated a higher CE than cycled in HCE ( Fig. 7a). The full cells of LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 | Li cycled in LHCE can show > 80% capacity retention after 700 cycles. Later, the Group optimized the carbonate-based LHCE to further improve the cycling stability of Li metal anode at lean electrolyte conditions. They developed an EC/EMC-based LHCE with lithium difluoro(oxalate)borate (LiDFOB) additive for LMBs [143]. As shown in Fig. 7b, replacing DMC with EC/EMC, the electrode surface showed a similar morphology after plating 1 mA h cm−2 Li on the Cu current collector. However, adding LiDFOB additive, a more uniform Li deposition can be observed. By XPS analysis, an improvement F content was found on the electrode surface after cycling in EC/EMC-based LHCE with LiDFOB additive, corresponding a more stable SEI layer. The LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 | Li full cells (cathode areal loading: 3.8 mA h cm−2) can exhibit 84% capacity retention after 100 cycles at lean electrolyte conditions.

At the mechanism level, Zhang Group investigated the reactivity of LHCE near the Li metal surface via density functional theory (DFT) calculations and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations [144]. The LHCE is prepared via dissolving 1 M LiFSI in a mixture of dimethoxyethane (DME)/tris(2,2,2-trifluoroethyl)orthoformate (TFEO) (v/v = 1:3). As shown in Fig. 7c, the Li–O interactions with FSI anion and DME are sharper than that with TFEO. They found that the defluorination of TFEO may contribute to the rapid formation of a stable SEI layer on the Li metal surface together with the anion decomposition; resulting in improved cycling stability. In LHCE, they found that when salt and TFEO molecules are close to each other and to the surface, fluoride anions resulting from the fast salt anion decomposition can trigger a cascade of reactions that lead to the decomposition of TFEO. However, if the Li cation is initially solvated by DME and the anion forming a complex, the stability of the anion increases significantly. Since DME is also much more stable compared to the anion, a compact SEI is formed due mainly to anion and limited TFEO decomposition. Recently, their Group reported a novel localized high-concentration sulfone electrolytes, which was prepared by diluting tetramethylene sulfone (TMS)-based HCE with a non-solvating fluorinated ether, 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropyl ether (TTE) [145]. Different from traditional diluent, the partial substitution of F atoms greatly reduces the solubility of LiFSI in TTE, but it is still completely miscible with TMS. Therefore, in localized high-concentration sulfone electrolytes, LiFSI only interacts with TMS. Meantime, the high viscosity and poor wettability issues of sulfone-based HCE were addressed by the introduction of TTE. In dilute electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 7d, the deposited Li showed dendritic growth and highly porous structure, which reduced the CE. In HCE, although the size of deposited Li was larger and CE was also significantly improved, the thickness of deposition Li layer was even higher. However, in localized high-concentration sulfone electrolytes, larger and denser Li particles were formed, which reduced the side reaction between Li metal and electrolyte, improving CE and cycling stability. More importantly, the LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 | Li full cells can exhibit a high discharge specific capacity at 0 °C even −10 °C, indicating a good prospect of practical application.

In brief, LHCE not only retains the advantages of traditional high concentration electrolyte, but also solves many problems in practical application of high concentration electrolyte systems. However, the application of LHCE is still faced with many challenges, for example: all current diluents have low boiling point and are easy to volatilize. Just from the molecular design, more researches should focus on improving the boiling point of diluent. Maybe increasing the degree of fluorination or extending alkyl side chain is a feasible method. For instance, the diluent of OFE displays more outstanding electrochemical property than TTE and BTFE.

Compared with the design of solvents and Li salts, modifying electrolyte with additives is considered the most convenient and economical strategy to suppress the formation Li dendrites and improve the CE of Li metal anode. Some additives can react with Li metal to form a stable SEI layer during the initial activation cycles, which suppresses dendritic growth and improves the cycling stability of Li metal anode. Some additives can induce Li deposition and regulate the Li+ flux on electrode surface. Even some additives can give the flammable electrolyte a flame-retarded nature and improve safety. Thus, a large number of additives were developed in the past decades.

Li metal can react with solvent and Li salts in electrolyte to form an unstable SEI film during cycling. Therefore, a good SEI-formation additive should have a low LUMO energy, which ensures it can be easier to be reduced than solvent and Li salts on Li metal surface [146,147]. Zhang et al. found that the fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) additive in 1.0 M LiPF6-EC/DEC can help from a compact and stable LiF-rich SEI layer ( Fig. 8a) [148]. The LUMO energy of FEC (−0.87 eV) is lower than EC (−0.38 eV) and DEC (0 eV), indicating FEC can be reduced preferentially on Li metal surface to form stable SEI layer. The Cu | Li exhibited a high CE of 98% and low over-potential of 50 mV after adding 5% FEC into electrolyte. With FEC additive, the LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 | Li full cells (cathode areal loading: 12 mg cm−2) showed a high specific discharge capacity of 154 mA h g−1 at 1.0 C. Similar to FEC, vinylene carbonate (VC) is often used as electrolyte additive for protecting Li metal anode. Yamaki et al. investigated the surface properties of deposited Li on Ni substrate in LiPF6-EC/DMC electrolyte with 2% VC additive. VC can be reduced by Li metal to form a stable SEI layer on Li electrode surface via ring-opening polymerization [149–151].

In addition to VC, FEC et al. solvent analogs, Li salts are also a common SEI-formation additive. LiNO3 is widely used as an electrolyte additive to suppress shuttle effect and protect Li metal anode in Li–S batteries [152–154]. In Li–S batteries system, a stable SEI layer containing organic component (ROCO2Li, ROLi) and inorganic component (LixNOy, LixSOy) can be formed after adding LiNO3. Beyond that, lithium sulfide and halide can also be used as SEI-formation additive to protect Li metal anode. Zhang Group proposed a sulfurized SEI layer with high Li+ diffusion rate to regulate uniform Li+ ﬂux and suppress dendritic growth [155]. As shown in Fig. 8b, after adding Li2S5 additive, a Li2S-containing SEI layer can be obtained, in which Li2S can prevent the growth of other inorganic crystals, leading a polycrystalline and mosaic-like SEI layer with poor crystallinity, thereby forming rapid Li+ diffusion channels. Thus, the Li | Li cells can cycle stably over 150 h at high current density of 5.0 mA cm−2.

Besides, dual-salts additives have also been attempted to protect Li metal anode. For example, adding LiPF6 and LiAsF6 into electrolyte can also suppress Li dendrites growth and improve the stability of Li metal anode. For the LiPF6-containing electrolyte, the trace amount of strong Lewis acids, PF5 and POF3, generated by the thermal decomposition and/or hydrolysis of the added LiPF6, was thought to help induce the formation of polycarbonate species through the ring-opening polymerization of EC [156,157]. Besides, Cui et al. found that the growth of Li dendrites can be suppressed effectively after adding lithium polysulfide (Li2S8) and LiNO3 additives into ether-based electrolyte [158]. A uniform and stable SEI layer can be formed on Li surface due to the synergetic effect of Li2S8 and LiNO3 additives, which inhibits dendritic growth and minimizes electrolyte decomposition (Fig. 8c). Via optimizing the concentration of Li2S8 and LiNO3 additives, a dendrite-free Li deposition can be observed in the in-situ optical experiment and the Li metal anode can maintain a high CE of > 99% over 300 cycles at high current density of 2.0 mA cm−2.

Except for Li salts additives, Guo et al. proposed to use AlCl3 as additive for achieving dendrite-free Li deposition and improving the CE of Li metal anode [159]. As shown in Fig. 8d, after introducing AlCl3 additive into electrolyte, the Al3+ can react with the trace amounts of H2O in electrolyte to produce Al(OH)3 nano-particles. Then Al(OH)3 nano-particles can absorb the excess Al3+ to form positively charged colloidal particles (PCCPs), thereby producing Al2O3 particles. The Al2O3 particles will precipitate on Li metal surface, and form a stable and dense Al-containing SEI layer. Therefore, the CE of Li metal anode can improve to 99% at 0.5 mA cm−2 in carbonate electrolyte.

Apart from the above-mentioned SEI-formation additive, inorganic acids and inorganic nanoparticles can also help form stable SEI layer on Li metal anode. Huang et al. proposed a Li metal protection method for Li–O2 batteries by using boric acid (BA) additive [160]. BA can react with LiOH/Li2O on Li surface to produce Li borates with covalently linked continuous O–B–O skeleton, forming a continuous and dense SEI layer on Li metal surface. As shown in Fig. 8e, the side reactions between Li metal and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) were inhibited after soaking Li metal in DMSO with BA. With BA additive, the Li–O2 batteries showed an improved cycling stability. Li et al. proposed a series of metal-organic framework (MOF) particles as SEI-formation additive [161]. They found that Zr-based MOF additive (UiO-66) in LiPF6-EC/DMC electrolyte can enable an ultra-long cycling of Li plating/stripping with a small over-potential. That is mainly because a reinforced SEI layer with concentrated LiF and robust Zr–O–C moieties was formed on Li metal surface after using UiO-66 additive. Li4Ti5O12 | Li full cells based on UiO-66 additive demonstrated a high reversibility over 900 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 8f). Recently, Xie et al. reported the buckminsterfullerene (C60) additive for protecting Li metal anode [162]. As shown in Fig. 8g, after adding nitro-C60 into electrolyte, nitro-C60 can be absorbed on Li metal surface, and reduced into soluble NO2 − and insoluble C60. Then C60 absorbed on the uneven groove of Li surface, further inducing a homogeneous Li+ distribution due to its excellent Li+ affinity, while soluble NO2 − can react with Li metal to form a dense and stable Li3N-rich SEI layer. Therefore, With 5 mM nitro-C60 additive, Li | Li symmetric cells can cycle stably in both carbonate and ether electrolytes. Li–S cells exhibited a capacity decay rate as low as 0.07% per cycle along with 500 cycles at 2.0 C.

In addition, some acidic gas, such as CO2 [163–165], HF [166], even trace amounts of H2O have been proved to be a SEI-formation additive in liquid electrolytes [167–169]. These additives can increase the content of inorganic species (such as: Li2O, Li2S, Li2CO3, LiF et al.) in SEI layer, which improves the stability of SEI layer and enables uniform Li+ diffusion.

Different from above-mentioned SEI-formation additives, Zhang Group proposed a novel mechanism, which can fundamentally alter the formation of Li dendrites by using Cs+ and Rb+ as additive [170]. According to the Nernst equation, when the concentration of Cs+/Rb+ is less than 0.05 M the eﬀective reduction potential of Cs+/Rb+ is lower than that of Li+ at 1.0 M (−3.04 V). Therefore, during Li deposition, Cs+/Rb+ will adsorb on the Li surface and can not form Li alloys layers on electrode surface. When an uneven Li deposition surface is formed, the high charge density at the protuberances will attract more Cs+/Rb+ near the tip to form an electrostatic shield. The positively charged shield will repel Li+ and force Li+ to deposit in adjacent regions, resulting in a smooth and dendrite-free Li metal surface ( Fig. 9a). With 0.05 M CsPF6 additive, Li4Ti5O12 | Li full cells showed > 95% capacity retention after 600 cycles at 1.0 C.

Comparing with the single functional SEI-formation additives, dual-functional or even multifunctional electrolyte additives have attracted wider attention in recent years. Ma et al. reported a bifunctional anionic electrolyte additive for protecting Li metal anode: tris (2, 2, 2-trifluoroethyl) borate (TTFEB) [171]. As shown in Fig. 9b, TTFEB can be preferentially reduced on Li metal surface, leading the formation of LiF-rich SEI layer. B-based compounds derived from TTFEB can tether the PF6 − and improve the Li+ transference number of electrolyte, which is beneficial to Li+ migration and uniform Li deposition. Therefore, with 2% TTFEB additive, Cu | Li exhibited a high CE of 96% in ester-based electrolyte. LiFePO4 | Li full cells can run stably over 500 cycles with high CE (> 99.5%). Huo et al. demonstrated Li-protective layer via thionyl chloride (SOCl2) additive for stabilizing Li–S batteries [172]. The SOCl2 can spontaneously react with Li metal to produce LiCl, Li2SO3, and S. Then a LiCl-rich SEI layer can be formed on the Li metal surface and generated S can act as “redox-additives” to offer extra capacity for Li–S batteries (Fig. 9c). Meantime, a stable and dense SEI layer can suppress the “shuttle effect” in Li–S batteries. The Li–S batteries based SOCl2 additive delivered an ultra-high discharge specific capacity of 2202.3 mA h g−1 at 400 mA g−1 and excellent rate performance (1348.6 mA h g−1 at 3000 mA g−1).

Apart from Li–S batteries, the multifunctional electrolyte additive can also be used in the LMBs paired with commercial cathodes. Sun Group developed a novel adiponitrile (C6H8N2) for high-performance Li[NixCoyMn1−x-y]O2 | Li batteries [173]. As shown in Fig. 9d, adding 1 wt% C6H8N2 into electrolyte, a conductive and robust SEI layer can be formed on Li metal surface, while a strong coordination between nitrile group and Ni4+ on the delithiated Ni-rich cathode surface can reduce the side reactions between Ni-rich cathode surface and electrolyte, means a stable cathode/ electrolyte interface. Therefore, under high-capacity loading of 1.8 mA h cm−2, Li[Ni0.73Co0.1Mn0.15Al0.02]O2 | Li full cells demonstrated an extremely high cycling stability and CE (> 99.5%) over 830 cycles. Besides, Xiang Group proposed a multifunctional electrolyte additive for LMBs using high-voltage LiCoO2 cathode [174]. As shown in Fig. 9e, introducing ethyl 5-amino-4-cyano-3-(2-ethoxycarbonylmethyl) thiophene-2-carboxylate (TAEC) into electrolyte, the TAEC can be preferentially oxidized to form a stable cathode/electrolyte interface (CEI) to protect cathode materials and prevent further electrolyte decomposition. Meanwhile, the –NH2 group of TAEC can combine H+ to form ammonium cations, which can absorb on the tip of Li dendrites to form an electrostatic shield, leading a smooth Li deposition surface. With 0.3 wt% TAEC, LiCoO2 | Li full cells can deliver a high discharge specific capacity of 162.7 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles.

Recently, some novel mechanisms based on electrolyte additive were developed to protect Li metal anode and suppress the formation/growth of Li dendrites. Dai et al. proposed a surfactant-based additive, hexadecyl trimethylammonium chloride (CTAC), to achieve uniform Li deposition [175]. As shown in Fig. 10a, with CTAC in electrolyte, when an uneven Li deposition surface is formed, the CTA+ will be adsorbed around the protuberant tips by electrostatic interactions. Meantime, the protuberant tips have higher surface free energy, which will absorb more CTAC molecules. Then, a large number of CTAC molecules will be absorbed on the protuberant regions due to electrostatic interactions and high surface free energy, thereby leading the formation of cross-linked lithiophobic protective layer. During subsequent Li plating process, solvent Li+ can not transport through the protective layer, leading Li deposition is forced to adjacent regions, further forming a smooth Li metal surface. Therefore, with CTAC additive, Li | Li cells can stably cycle over 300 h at high current density of 4.0 mA cm−2, while Li–S cells can deliver a high discharge specific capacity of 962.8 mA h g−1 at 2.0 C and long cycling life (> 500 cycles).

Besides, our Group proposed to use poly(ethylene glycol)-200 (PEG-200) as additive for suppressing dendritic Li growth and improving the cycling stability of Li metal anode [176]. As shown in Fig. 10b, the PEG-200 molecule can be absorbed on Li metal surface and combine with Li+ to form Li+–PEG complex, thereby ensuring a homogeneous distribution of Li+ flux near the electrode surface and avoiding the formation of Li dendrites. With PEG-200 additive, Li | Li symmetrical cells can display a stable cycle over 500 h at ultrahigh current density of 10.0 mA h cm−2. LiFePO4 | Li full cells can cycle stably over 250 cycles with nearly 100% capacity retention. A similar result with a PEG-based electrolyte additive was also reported by Lai et al. [177]. As shown in Fig. 10c, after introducing octaphenyl polyoxyethylene (OP-10) additive into electrolyte, the OP-10 contain hydrophilic EO chains can coordinate with Li+ to form PEO/Li+ complexes near electrode surface, thereby regulating Li deposition. Long phenyl carbon chains in OP-10 can form a cross-linked network to enhance the chemical stability of the EO groups, avoiding the decomposition of OP-10 additive. Therefore, the LiFePO4 | Li full cells can run stably over 1000 cycles with high capacity retention.

Zhang et al. reported the use of nanodiamond additives in LiPF6-EC/DEC electrolyte to suppress dendritic Li growth [178]. As shown in Fig. 10d, nanodiamond can regulate Li deposition via follow four steps: 1) Li+ absorbs on nanodiamond rather than Cu because of the large specific surface area of nanodiamond; 2) Li+-nanodiamond is transported to Cu electrode surface under electric field force; 3) As a seed, nanodiamond induces initial Li nucleation; 4) Nanodiamond-guided Li deposition behaviors small crystal sizes and uniform surface due to the small sizes of nanodiamond particles. With nanodiamond additives, the Li metal anode showed a high CE of 96% in Li | Cu cells, while Li | Li symmetrical cells can display a stable cycle over 200 h at 1.0 mA h cm−2.

Very recently, Zhou et al. demonstrated a novel mechanism to suppress dendritic Li growth by a super filling mechanism [179]. As shown in Fig. 10e, with thiourea (THU) additive, the THU molecular is more favorable to be absorbed on Li metal surface than DME solvent molecule, then absorbed THU molecular can act as a nucleation site for accelerating Li deposition. When an uneven Li deposition surface is formed, THU is enriched on the concave surface rather than the convex surface after geometric deformation of the electrodes. In this situation, the Li+ tends to be reduced and deposit more quickly on the concave regions. With the extension of plating time, a smooth Li deposition layer can be obtained. After adding THU additive, Cu | Li half cells can cycle stably for 120 cycles at a high current density of 5.0 mA cm−2, and Li | Li cell can achieve stable cycling without any dendrite formation over 1000 cycles at high current densities of 5 mA cm−2. Moreover, with THU additive, Li metal dendrites can be self-healed and the Li metal batteries can be recovered from local inner short circuit and continue running well. Thus, the LiFePO4 | Li full cells showed a very high capacity retention of > 88% after 800 cycles at 1.0 C. Cui et al. proposed a nonreactive additive to suppress the formation of Li dendrites [180]. As shown in Fig. 10f, after adding nonreactive hexane into electrolyte, the nucleation and growth over-potentials of Li deposition showed a significant decrease, meanwhile, the CE can be improved to > 97% with hexane additive. The nonreactive hexane additive improved the interface wettability of electrolyte and enhanced the oxidative stability of polar solvent, thereby suppressing polar solvent decomposition on Li metal surface, ensuring a stable SEI layer and high cycling stability of LMBs.

Compared with above-mentioned methods, using non-flammable electrolytes can fundamentally eliminate the risk of fire hazards and improve the safety of LMBs. In the field of electrolytes, flash point and self-extinguishing time (SET) are commonly used to define the flammability. According to the SET, the electrolyte can be classified into three categories: if SET < 6 s/g, it is defined as non-flammable; if SET is between 6 and 20 s/g, it is defined as flame-retarded; if SET > 20 s/g, it is defined as flammable [181,182]. Maintaining combustion usually depends on the production of free radicals, and the ground state O2 molecular can produce singlet oxygen (
O
2
*
) after absorbing heat. Meantime, fuel absorbs heat to produce hydrogen radicals (H•), then
H O O
*
• can be formed by the combination of
O
2
*
and H•. These radicals have a very short lifetime and high reactivity, thereby producing a lot of heat [183]. Thus, based on this mechanism, non-flammable electrolyte was developed by reducing the ability to produce combustion free radicals (
O
2
*
, H•,
H O O
*
•) and enhancing the ability to eliminate these free radicals. After heating, flame-retardant additive can release a large number of free radicals which can capture these combustion free radicals (
O

, H•,
H O O
