•), thus blocking the chain reaction of free radicals. Common flame-retardant additives are phosphate-based agents, such as: mono alkyl phosphate, halogenated phosphite ester, halogenated phosphonates, etc. However, the introduction of flame retardants usually fails to form a stable SEI, leading to a significant reduction in electrochemical performance. Recently, with the development of high concentration electrolytes, this challenge seems to be avoidable, as the SEI is mainly derived from the decomposition of Li salts under high concentration electrolytes. Some novel non-flammable electrolyte systems based on phosphate ester have been developed. For example, Liu et al. prepared a phosphate-based non-flammable electrolyte consisting of lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI) and triethyl phosphate (TEP) [184]. By adjusting the molar ratio of Li salt to solvent, they found that solvent molecules are mostly coordinated with Li+ at high salt-to-solvent molar ratios (1:2), which inhibits the side reaction between non-combustible phosphate electrolyte and Li metal anode ( Fig. 11a). Cu | Li half cells can cycle stably for 100 cycles with a high CE of > 99%. Commercial 18,650 Li-ion cells using nonflammable electrolyte also exhibited high cycling stability, high CE (> 99.7%), and safe operation. Later, Liu et al. further confirmed that the ion-solvent-coordinated (ISC) nonflammable electrolyte can ensure a dendrite-free Li plating/stripping process (Fig. 11b) [185]. Meantime, they explored more deeply the reversibility of Li metal anode in a wide salt-to-solvent molar ratios range (1:5–1:1). The Cu | Li half cells can maintain high average CE of > 99.3% over 350 cycles when using LiFSI-TEP electrolyte (molar ratios = 1:1.5). Xu et al. also reported a phosphate-based non-flammable electrolytes consisting of 2.8 M LiTFSI in TEP with 10 vol% FEC (Fig. 11c) [186]. The additive of FEC can improve Li+ conductivity, reduce viscosity and ensure good wettability, while a stable LiF-rich SEI layer can be formed on the Li metal surface. The LiFePO4 | Li full cells exhibited a high capacity retention of > 90% over 2000 cycles at 1.0 C and a high rate specific capability of 103 mA h g−1 at 5.0 C.

Apart from phosphate-based non-flammable electrolytes, all-fluorinated electrolytes can also be developed for improving the safety of LMBs. That is because that fluorinated solvent usually has a high flash point or even no flash point, thereby improving the safety of electrolyte. Up to now, fluorinated solvents mainly include fluorinated ethers and fluorinated esters. Wang Group reported a novel all-fluorinated electrolyte consisting of 1 M LiPF6 in a mixture of fluoroethylene carbonate/3,3,3-fluoroethylmethyl carbonate/1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2′,2′,2′-trifluoroethyl ether (FEC:FEMC:HFE, 2:6:2 by weight) [187]. Different from previously reported fluorinated electrolytes, the all-fluorinated electrolyte enabled a high reversibility of Li metal anode, while suppressed dendritic Li growth without raising the interfacial impedance (Fig. 11d). An amorphous layer (5–10 nm) can be formed on the surface of cathode materials (such as: LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811), LiCoPO4 (LCP)) during cycling in all-fluorinated electrolyte. Thus, the NCM811 | Li full cells can run stably over 400 cycles with high average CE of 99.93%, and LCP | Li full cells can cycle stably over 1000 cycles with average CE of 99.83%.

There was another interesting all-fluorinated electrolyte reported by Li Group in which they dissolved 7 M LiFSI in FEC [188]. The electrolyte also displayed a non-flammability, and a stable LiF-rich SEI protective layer can be formed on Li metal surface during cycling in this electrolyte. The CE of Li metal anode can be improved to 99.64%, while the electrolyte behaviors excellent compatibility with 5 V LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode materials. Thus, the LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 | Li full cells displayed a high rate capacity and cycling stability (Fig. 11e).

Different from the all-fluorinated electrolyte based on ester solvent, a perfluoropolyether (PFPE)-based electrolyte was proposed by Xie et al. [189]. The PFPE-based electrolyte has high security, good compatibility with Al current collector, and non-flammability. Meantime, a thin and stable SEI layer can be obtained on Li metal surface in PFPE-MC/LiTFSI electrolytes (Fig. 11f). Li | Li cell can achieve stable cycling without any dendrite formation over 1600 h. LiFePO4 | Li full cells can exhibit a stable cycling performance with > 99.9% CE at ambient temperature and high temperature.

Very recently, a fluorinated electrolyte with non-polar solvents was proposed by Wang Group to improve the safety of LMBs, as shown in Fig. 11g [190]. The electrolyte was prepared by dissolving LiFSI-FEC/FEMC into non-polar stable solvents (tetrafluoro-1-(2,2,2-trifluoroethoxy)ethane (D2). The D2 is free solvent molecules, means it can’t coordinate with Li ions and anions. The polar FEC solvent, FEMC and LiFSI can help the formation of LiF-rich SEI layer, which can suppress dendritic Li growth efficiently. The designed electrolyte can demonstrate a high electrochemical stability, high ionic conductivity in a wide temperature range from −125 °C to 70 °C, a wide electrochemical window (0.0–5.6 V) and non-flammable characteristic. Thus, high-voltage LiCoMnO4 | Li full cells can display a high cycling stability and CE (>99%). Even under −85 °C, the LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 | Li full cells using the electrolyte can deliver 56% of its room-temperature capacity.

In all, electrolyte design based on liquid electrolyte is a key and efficient strategy to regulate Li deposition and improve the safety of LMBs, meanwhile, it is also easy to realize in industrial application. As shown in Fig. 12, if using Li metal anode, the space left for electrolyte is 25 wt% for a pouch cell with high energy density of > 350 W h kg−1, which is much higher than that in commercial LIBs based on graphite anode (~ 13%) [191]. Therefore, all electrolyte designs above-mentioned can ensure a high energy density once they're ready for practical application. However, there are still several key issues should be noted in future designs: a) the mechanism of dendritic formation and growth in liquid electrolyte; b) almost all additives are continuously consumed to help form a more stable SEI layer during cycling, means: these additives can hardly work forever; c) poor wettability and high-cost in high-concentration electrolytes and “solvent-in-salt” electrolytes; d) complicated preparation process and high-cost in all-fluorinated electrolytes; e) electrode compatibility and chemical stability. Although a lot of electrolyte systems have been reported in the literature, they fall short in one or more of these aspects. Thus, it is still extremely desired to develop efficient and feasible electrolyte systems. Electrolyte additive is the simplest strategy to inhibit dendritic Li growth and improve the cycling stability of LMBs. Even some flame retardant additive can greatly enhance the safety of LMBs. Thus, maybe it is an efficient method to solve these challenges by the synergistic effect of several strategies, such as: the combination of SEI-formation additive and flame retardant additive; the combination of high-concentration electrolyte and all-fluorinated electrolyte, and the combination of localized high-concentration electrolyte and flame retardant additive, et al.

Because of its superiorities in ionic conductivity, Li+ transportation, electrochemical windows and stability, ionic liquid electrolyte (ILE) has attracted remarkable attention from researchers [192–195]. ILE is composed of Li salts, solvated cations, solvated anions, and negligible free solvent molecules. Compared with traditional organic liquid electrolyte, high-efficiency Li metal cycling can be obtained in the ILE. At the same time, ILE also ensures the ability to form passivating SEI layers [196]. Generally, the formation of ILE mainly depends on the structure of solvents and Li salts. According to the composition of cations, ionic liquid can be divided into tetralkylammonium, phosphonium, imidazolium, pyrrolidium, piperidinium, etc. Among that, because of the mechanism of Li+ migration, glyme-based ILE is most widely studied and used, in which glyme-based means: triglyme and tetraglyme or their derivatives [197]. For example, Imanishi et al. reported an electrolyte system of tetraglyme and LiFSI to suppress dendritic growth at high current density. They found that the highest occupied molecular orbital energy of the tetraglyme can be reduced by complexing with Li+, thereby improving the electrochemical stability of tetraglyme. The Li anode demonstrated a high areal capacity of 12.0 mA h cm−2 for 40 cycles even at a high current density of 6.0 mA cm−2 at 60 °C. Besides, the SEI film is also influenced by the solvated structure of Li+ in ILE. A typical work was reported by Watanabe Group, in which they prepared three ILEs with various molar ratios LiTFSI:triglyme = 1.00:1.25; 1.00:1.00; 1.00:0.80 and confirmed that increasing the content of Li salts in the ILE can effectively control the interfacial degradation and suppress the formation of Li dendrites [198]. When the molar ratio of LiTFSI:triglyme = 1.00:0.80, a long-lived, robust Li+ solvation complexes can be achieved, and excess Li salts can be used to compensate for Li+ at the interface between electrode and electrolyte during the charge/discharge process, ensuring stable cycling performance of Li metal anode.

Although the use of ILE can improve the cycling performance of Li anode to some extent, its further application is hindered by high viscosity and low ionic conductivity. Generally speaking, the viscosity of ionic liquids with TFSI− anions is mainly affected by cations, because the TFSI- anions are highly symmetric in space structure, means: its structure is close to electroneutral structure, in which the charge distribution is uniform and the electrostatic force between Li+ and TFSI- is similar to van der Waals’ force. The influence of cation on the structure mainly depends on the composition of the cation. Its branch chain and space structure have a significant effect on the viscosity of the ionic liquid. Hence, just from molecular level, some groups are usually introduced into the cation of ionic liquid, such as: methyl-propyl structure, ethyl-butyl structure [199,200]. In this way, the viscosity of ionic liquid can be reduced as much as possible, and the system can maintain an ideal structure.

Functionalized ionic liquids have attracted more and more attention in recent years. It means that: connecting functional alkyl groups in the cationic side chain of ionic liquids, such as: ‒CH3OCH3, ‒NH2, ‒SH, ‒NHCONH2, ‒OH, ‒SO3H [201,202]. After introducing functional groups, various ionic liquids with new structures can be created, while their physical and chemical properties can be significantly changed. Among them, ionic liquids containing ether oxygen functional groups or cyano functional groups have been studied more. After introducing functional groups (ether group, nitrile group) into ionic liquids, the electrons can transfer from ether group to cation center, thereby reducing the positive charge effect of N atom, thus the electrostatic interaction between cation and anion can be reduced. Another explanation is that the flexible structure of functionalized groups is beneficial to the movement of ions, which reduces the viscosity of ionic liquids, thereby improving the conductivity of ILE and reducing the activation energy of the system.

Besides, some Groups concentrated on finding various diluents. Watanabe Group diluted the ILE by various molecular solvents and investigated the solvation of Li+ using diffusivity measurements and Raman spectroscopy [203]. They showed that the polarity of diluents was a key factor to influence the stability of ILE and Li metal anode. If using highly polar solvents such as H2O and PC, the coordinate structure between Li+ and glyme might be destroyed. However, in less polar solvents or moderately polar solvents, such as: toluene, DEC, acetonitrile, et al., the glyme molecules preferentially coordinated to Li+, and the coordinate structure between Li+ and glyme is still stable, thereby much better cycling stability can be achieved.

Hybrid ionic liquid electrolyte is also an effective strategy to control the formation of SEI film and improve the electrochemical performance of Li metal anode in ILE. Guo Group proposed a promising Li metal passivation strategy by using hybrid N-propyl-N-methylpyrrolidinium bis(triﬂuoromethanesulfonyl)amide (Py13TFSI) and ether electrolyte [204]. As shown in Fig. 13a, the hybrid electrolyte can enhance the stability of SEI layer by the in situ passivation process, thus, the dendritic Li growth and metallic Li corrosion can be efficiently restrained during charging/discharging process. The reversibility of Li plating/stripping can be remarkably improved by the synergy between Py13TFSI ionic liquid and Li salt concentration. However, Py13-based ILs still have high viscosity, which is bad for the improvement of cycling performance in full cells with high cathode mass loading. Recently, Dai Group proposed a novel nonﬂammable ILE composed of 1-ethyl-3 methylimidazolium (EMIm) cations, high-concentration bis(ﬂuorosulfonyl)imide (FSI) anions and sodium bis(triﬂuoromethanesulfonyl)imide (NaTFSI) [205]. As shown in Fig. 13b, this novel IlE exhibited a viscosity of ≈ 125 mPa s at 22 °C, about half of Py13-based ILs. The Na+ participates in the formation of hybrid SEI passivation layer and contributes to dendrite-free Li deposition and reversible cathode electrochemistry. Benefit from that, symmetrical Li | Li cells can achieve stable cycling without any dendrite formation over 1200 h, and Li redox CE ≈ 99% in Li | Cu cells over 400 cycles. When the NCM cathode mass loading up to 12 mg cm−2, the full cells can exhibit a high CE of 99.6–99.9%, high discharge voltages up to 4.4 V, high specific capacity of ≈ 199 mA h g−1 and high energy density of ≈ 765 W h kg−1 with impressive cycling performances over 1200 cycles. This is one of the most stable Li metal-based full cells to date.

Besides, some ionic liquids can absorb on the Li(001) surface to control the component of SEI film. A typical work was reported by Breedon Group, in which they calculated the adsorption energy of the ionic liquid ethylammonium tetrafluoroborate [EtNH3 +][BF4 −] on a Li(001) surface and simulated the initial process of the SEI layer formation (Fig. 13c). They found that the BF4 − ion binds via three F atoms to three or four Li surface atoms forming a Li3,4–BF4 surface bound cluster, which will help form a stable LiF-rich SEI layer [206]. This work offers an improved understanding of SEI layer formation and provides a design principle for ILE.

Inorganic-organic ionic liquid electrolyte is also a research hotspot [207–209]. Lu et al. synthesized two inorganic-organic ionic liquid electrolytes, means: SiO2-nanoparticle-tethered 1-methy-3-propylimidazolium TFSI (SiO2-IM-TFSI) and 1-methy-3-propylpiperidinium TFSI (SiO2-PP-TFSI) and investigated their ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability, mechanical properties, et al. [210]. As shown in Fig. 14a, the tethered IL component provides a source of nearly immobile, un-dissociated counterions throughout the interelectrode space, potentially allowing for rapid replenishment of counterions upon cell polarization, thereby improving the Li+ transference number. They found that PP-based electrolytes are more conductive and substantially more efficient in suppressing dendritic Li growth. With both ILEs, the cell lifetime can be improved over 10,000-fold.

Similar to traditional liquid electrolyte, increasing the concentration of Li salts in ILE was also developed to improve the electrochemical performance of Li metal anode at high current density. Howlett et al. reported a superconcentrated LiFSI in [C3mpyr][FSI] ILE for the first time [211]. With this superconcentrated ILE, a stable and LiF-rich SEI, favorable nucleation and compact dendrite-free Li morphology can be achieved. Hence, the CE of Li metal anode can be improved from 64 ± 3% at 1 mA cm−2 up to 96 ± 1% at 20 mA cm−2 on a bare Ni substrate. Symmetrical Li | Li cells can also achieve high cycling stability (Fig. 14b). However, using highly concentrated ILE would result in a poor separator compatibility. Considering this challenge, a recent study showed that the choice of separator plays a critical role in the cycle life of Li metal cells with high current density [212]. The commercial celgard 3501 separator does not show superior transport or wetting properties when compared to another separator of whatman GF/A. Separator with small pore size can ensure high wettability and prevent the occurrence of short circuiting efficiently (Fig. 14c).

In short, ionic liquid electrolyte has been considered as a “best-of-both-worlds” candidate because of its negligible volatility and nonflammability. Because the anions and cations of ionic liquids can be freely combined according to the needs of researchers. However, high viscosity and low ionic conductivity limit its further application and using ILE could not completely suppress or eliminate the growth of dendrites. Although a lot of works have been reported to overcome these issues, it is still hard to obtain a particular ILE which can meet various requirements for abundant practical applications. Up to date, for ionic liquid electrolyte designs, a widely accepted strategy is to form gel electrolytes by combining with polymer.

Gel electrolyte (GE) has attracted a large amount of researches because of combining the advantages of both liquid electrolytes and polymer electrolytes [213–217]. GE generally consisted of Li salts, polymer matrix, and a small amount of organic solvents, it has high Li+ conductivity, wide electrochemical window and good thermal stability. Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) is one of the most common polymer matrix because it not only has high electrochemical stability toward cathode materials (LCO, NCM et al.), but also is helpful for stabilizing the SEI layer on the Li electrode surface [218,219]. A typical work was reported by Jin Group, in which they designed an ionic liquid-immobilized polymer gel electrolyte [220]. Such a GE provides high Li+ conductivity, wide voltage window, strong mechanical strength and even self-healing properties. As shown in Fig. 15a, compared to traditional liquid electrolyte, the GE with tethered TFSI anions can regulate the Li+ flux near electrode surface, thereby restraining Li dendritic growth during Li plating/stripping process. Meantime, the strong ion-dipole interactions in cross-linked matrix result in enlarged amorphous regions and immobilized TFSI anions, thereby improving the Li+ conductivity. Hence， the symmetrical Li | Li cells can achieve stable cycling without any dendrite formation over 1000 h at 1.0 mA cm−2. And the LiFePO4 | Li full cells exhibited a high capacity retention of ≈ 100% over 200 cycles at 1.0 C.

Apart from using pure PVDF matrix, some nanoparticles are also introduced into the PVDF matrix to improve Li+ conductivity and mechanical stability, such as: Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, Li3N, LiAg4I5, γ-LiAlO2, Li7La3Zr2O12, et al. Li et al. introduced laponite (LAP) into the PVDF matrix for fabricating a high-performance GE [221]. As shown in Fig. 15b, after adding LAP particles, the abundant hydroxyls in LAP can strongly bond with fluorine in PVDF, leading to the high dispersion of LAP nanoplates, thereby reducing the crystallinity of PVDF and improving the Li+ conductivity. Benefit from this, the LiFePO4 | Li full cells exhibited a high capacity retention (> 97%) and long cycling stability (> 1000 cycles). Furthermore, it is also an effective strategy to modify PVDF-based gel electrolyte by designing electrolyte structure. Liu et al. proposed a novel asymmetric PVDF-based GE to improve the Li+ mobility and ionic conductivity by a modified freeze-casting approach [222]. As shown in Fig. 15c, this structure consists of two layers: 1) a vertically aligned channel array layer; 2) a nanoporous layer with an average pore size of 150 nm. Such a two-layer structure combined with dipoles from the PVDF-HFP matrix enables the asymmetric GE to present superior Li+ conductivity, and thus retards Li dendrite formation. With this asymmetric GE, the LiFePO4 | Li full cells delivered a high initial discharge capacity of 156 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and excellent rate performance (101 mA h g−1 at 5.0 C). Certainly, some other common polymers with high electrochemical stability can also be used as polymer matrix in GE, such as: poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) and poly(vinylidene fluoride-cohexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) et al. [223,224]. Recently, Shao et al. designed a smart lithiophilic polymer-filler-reinforced gel polymer electrolyte, which was shown in Fig. 15d. The authors choose lithiophilic polyacenequinone (PQ) polymer as the filter and thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) as the polymer electrolyte matrix to prepare the polymer-filler-reinforced GE. The abundant carbonyl groups can form hydrogen-bonded networks in composite matrix, enabling high Li+ conductivity and robust mechanical strength. Li+ in the GE could be tethered by the lithiophilic carbonyl groups of the PQ filter, thereby ensuring homogeneous Li+-flux at the interface. The Li-reactive chemical properties of PQ polymer can consume Li dendrites as soon as they penetrate into GE, thus guaranteeing the stable and safe run of LMBs. As a result, the symmetrical Li | Li cells can achieve stable cycling with a low over-potential of 25 mV over 700 h. Even when paired with a high-voltage NCM622 cathode, the LMBs also can maintain a high CE of > 99% over 100 cycles [225].

Besides, the strategy of inorganic-organic composition is also used to improve the properties of GE [226–231]. SiO2 nanoparticles have been widely reported as ceramic fillers in GE to improve the mechanical properties and thermal stability [232,233]. Recently, Goodenough Group reported a nano-SiO2-supported gel polymer electrolyte with a hierarchical structure fabricated in situ gelation of a traditional organic liquid electrolyte, which was shown in Fig. 16a. Firstly, hydrophilic SiO2 was surface-modified to introduce the isocyanate group; then the isocyanate group was hydrolyzed to produce carboxyl, and the proton from carboxyl initiated the ring-opening polymerization of DOL. The GE finally displayed high Li+ conductivity of 1.98 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C and wide electrochemical window of > 4.9 V. The full cells paired with LFP cathode demonstrated a high discharge capacity of 157.3 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 C [234].

Except for modifying polymer matrix or designing structure, Li salts are also a key part of GE. Meanwhile, a lot of reports emphasized that the Li salts system (especially dual Li salts system) is proved to be valid for stabilizing the electrode/electrolyte interface, thereby improving ionic conductivity, and further reducing the capacity loss in the long cycling [235–237]. Based on this, Guo et al. proposed a novel dual-salt (LiTFSI-LiPF6) GE with 3D cross-linked polymer network, which was shown in Fig. 16b. Multiple reaction sites of poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) and ethoxylated trimethylolpropane triacrylate (ETPTA) enable the formation of 3D cross-linked structure under thermal initiation. The introduction of dual salt improves the ionic conductivity and enhances the stability of SEI layer. Hence, the GE can suppress Li dendritic growth effectively and the full cells with LFP cathode can exhibit a high capacity retention of 87.93% after 300 cycles [238].

However, the Li+ transference number in GE with traditional Li salts is generally lower than 0.5 because of the concentration polarization and limitation of polymer host. Thus, single Li+ GE attracts wide attention due to its high Li+ transference number and relative high conductivity. A typical work was reported by Xu Group, which was shown in Fig. 16c. The PEGDA was introduced as cross-linked agent to improve the mechanical properties of GE, while the EO groups into the branches were helpful for Li+ migration. The introduction of –C6H4−SO2−N−–SO2‒CF3 (STFSI−) anions in GE can enhance the Li+ conductivity by suppressing the formation of ion-pairing between counter ions and Li+. Thus, both the symmetric cells and full cells with LFP cathode demonstrated high cycling stability [239].

Beyond aiming to Li salts or polymer matrix, Cui et al. aimed SEI layer and developed a unique polymer matrix for GE which can participate in building a stable polymer-integrated SEI layer during cycling [240]. As shown in Fig. 17a, the authors proposed a homopolymer (PCUMA)-based GPE (PCUMA-GPE) of cyclic carbonate urethane methacrylate (2-(((2-oxo-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl)methoxy) carbonylamino)ethyl methacrylate, CUMA) via an in situ polymerization method, in which the abundant rigid cyclic carbonate motifs on PCUMA could participate in in situ building a robust polymer-reinforced SEI layer during charging/discharging cycling. Meanwhile, the PCUMA-GPE displayed a good ionic conductivity of 1.27 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 30 °C, a high decomposition potential up to 5 V and a large Li+ transference number of 0.44. The full cells paired with LCO cathode demonstrated a high capacity retention of > 92% after 200 cycles at 0.5 C. Besides, some Groups also targeted the combination between gel electrolyte and solid-state electrolyte to improve the mechanical strength and electrochemical/thermal stability. Zhong et al. reported an ultra-robust composite gel electrolyte (CGE), which was shown in Fig. 17b. The gel electrolyte matrix was fabricated by compositing bacterial cellulose (BC) and Li3xLa2/3−xTiO3 nanowires (LLTO NWs) into a 3D structured aerogel. Owing to the synergistic effect derived from robust 3D porous BC as a skeleton and LLTO NWs being able to immobilize anions, the as-obtained CGE exhibited excellent mechanical strength (Young’s modulus is 1.15 GPa) and high Li+ transference number of 0.88, thereby effectively suppressing the dendritic Li growth [241]. With this CGE, the symmetric Li | Li cells exhibited a long cycle life of 1200 h and even at a high current density of 5.0 mA cm−2.

Recently, Luo Group reported an interesting work, in which they proposed a zwitterionic gel electrolyte [242]. As shown in Fig. 17c, the zwitterionic compound in GE can restrain the motion of TFSI anions, preventing anion depletion near the anode region. Meantime, both cationic and anionic functional groups in the zwitterionic chains can absorb anions and Li+ in GE, thereby regulating the Li+-flux distribution. Thus, the novel zwitterionic gel electrolyte can promote the dissociation of Li salts and efficiently prevent the formation of space charge layer via local anion depletion, avoiding the dendritic Li growth. Lastly, the Li+ transference number was improved to 0.63 and symmetric Li | Li cells exhibited stable voltage profile without any dendritic growth.

Further, considering the cathode materials, some gel electrolytes with the function of trapping transition metal ions might be more efficient in practical LMBs [243–245]. A typical work was reported by Yang et al., in which they designed a novel bifunctional biobased composite gel electrolyte to concurrently deal with the two issues of Li dendrites and Mn ions dissolution and migration in LMBs [246]. As shown in Fig. 17d, the skeleton of the GE was consisted of a layer of mesoporous polydopamine spheres (PDSs), two layers of nanofiber membranes containing biodegradable soy protein isolate (SPI), and a layer of mesoporous carbonized polydopamine spheres (CPDSs). Such a skeleton material exhibited excellent thermal stability and good affinity to liquid electrolyte, endowing the GE with significant functions of effective mitigation of the dissolution of Mn ions, and chelation of the ﬂeeing Mn ions, as well as the dramatic suppression of Li dendrite growth. Thus, the full cells with LiMn2O4 cathode displayed an improved rate performance (65.5 mA h g−1 at 2.0 C) and high capacity retention (71.3% after 200 cycles).

A simple overview, current developed gel electrolytes have remarkable properties, such as: high ionic conductivity, excellent compatibility with Li metal anode, wide electrochemical window, et al. However, it is still hard to avoid leakage in high temperature environment, which leads to safety concern. Therefore, we appeal to researchers to devote to the development of non-flammable electrolyte or solid-state electrolyte. It's just a personal opinion, GE is hard to be used in future Li metal batteries because its cost, security, stability and so on.

Using solid-state electrolyte (SSE) to replace traditional liquid electrolyte is regarded as an ultimate solution to improve the cycling stability and security of LMBs [247–251]. SSE has high mechanical strength and chemical inertness, which can effectively suppress the growth of Li dendrites and reduce the interfacial side reactions [252–255]. Furthermore, the LMBs using SSE are also exposed to have higher energy density. According to the composition, SSE falls into two major types: inorganic solid electrolytes and polymer electrolytes. The common inorganic solid electrolytes are as follows: lithium phosphorous oxynitride (LiPON), perovskite-type, garnet-type, and sulfide-type. The polymer electrolytes are mainly based on poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO), poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), poly(acrylonitrile) (PAN), poly(propylene oxide) (PPO) and poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) et al.

Inorganic sulfide solid electrolytes have been extensively studied for solid Li metal batteries because they have a high ionic conductivity at room temperature (over 1 mS cm−1) and a wide electrochemical window (5.0 V vs. Li/Li+) [256–258]. Among them, Li2S–P2S5 based solid electrolytes are one of the most extensively studied systems. There is an interesting phenomenon that the ionic conductivity of Li2S–P2S5 stable phases (γ) is very low, but the ionic conductivity of Li2S–P2S5 amorphous phases (β) is high [259]. Early on, Yamane et al. prepared the Li2S–P2S5 sulfide solid electrolyte by mechanical milling [260]. They found that the structure of Li2S–P2S5 varied with the preparation temperature. When the temperature < 190 °C, γ-Li2S–P2S5 with low conductivity can be obtained, while if the temperature > 190 °C, β-Li2S–P2S5 in crystalline phase with high ionic conductivity would be achieved. To further improve the ionic conductivity of Li2S–P2S5, appropriate doping strategies were proposed. Structurally, doping in the sulfide solid electrolytes can not only produce point defects, but also broaden the channels of Li+ transmission, thereby greatly improving the Li+ conductivity [261–265]. A typical work was reported by Tu et al., in which they used MoS2 doping to enhance the ionic conductivity of Li2S–P2S5 sulfide solid electrolyte [266]. After doping, the Li+ conductivity can be improve to 4.8 mS cm−1, meanwhile, the all-solid-state Li–S cells exhibited a high discharge capacity of 1020 mA h g−1. Talking about all-solid-state Li–S cells based on Li2S–P2S5 solid electrolyte, there is another impressive work, which was reported by Ci Group [267]. As shown in Fig. 18a, they prepared an all-solid-state Li–S cell consisting of a Li7P3S11 solid electrolyte, Si anode coated by Li7P3S11 and Li2S/graphene composite cathode. Benefit from the high capacity of Si anode and Li2S cathode, this battery yields a high theoretical specific energy density up to 1495 W h kg−1. Moreover, they claimed that Li2S cathode is used as Li source instead of using Li metal anode, avoiding interface reaction between Li metal anode and sulfide electrolyte and improving the security of LMBs. However, it seems that only using Li2S/graphene as Li source is not enough to overcome the interface problems between lithium metal and electrolyte.

Recently, there are some new sulfide solid electrolytes with high ionic conductivity have been developed, such as Li10GeP2S12, LixAlyS et al. [268]. Kanno and Hirayama designed a bulk-type 5 V-class all solid-state battery consisting of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode, Li10GeP2S12 solid-electrolyte, and Li metal anode, in which they modified LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 with a LiNbO3 coating layer to facilitate lithium diffusion at high voltages above 4.5 V [269]. On the electrolyte/Li side, the Li10GeP2S12 could be decomposed to form a SEI layer containing Li2S during the initial cycles, resulting in reversible electrochemical reactions and improving electrochemical kinetics process (Fig. 18b). Thus, the average voltage of the discharge curves of the bulk-type 5 V-class all solid-state battery remain at about 4.3 V. The same year, they also proposed a strategy of partially replacing sulfur with oxygen in Li10GeP2S12 solid electrolyte to improve the electrochemical stability [270]. They found that the partial substitution of S did not dramatically lower the ionic conductivity from the original Li10GeP2S12. The method might be an effective strategy for balancing the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability. Another new type of sulfide solid electrolyte (LixAlyS) was also developed to stabilize Li metal anode, a typical work was reported by W. Elam Group [271]. They designed a thin LixAlyS coating on Li metal anode via ALD method. This film showed a high Li+ conductivity of 2.5 × 10−7 S cm−1 at room temperature, reducing the interfacial impedance of Li metal anode in contact with organic electrolyte.

Besides, garnet-like structural compounds can also be used as a fast Li+ conductor. Among them, Li5La3Ta2O12 (LLTO) and Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) have generated much attention because of their stability in the presence of Li metal [272–278]. As early as in 2013, Kotobuki Group investigated in detail the chemical and electrochemical properties of LLTO [279]. They reported that a well-sintered LLTO pellet with a garnet-like structure can be achieved when the sintering temperature > 1200 °C. The LLTO pellet showed a high Li ion conductivity of 1.3 × 10−4 S cm−1 and wide electrochemical window of 5.0 V. Recently, Wang et al. prepared a perovskite-type LLTO freestanding ceramic electrolyte film by tape-casting, which was show in Fig. 18c. Compared to the thick electrolyte (> 200 µm) obtained by cold-pressing, the electrolyte prepared by tape-casting displayed a high Li ion conductivity of 2.0 × 10−5 S cm−1 and low thickness of 25 µm, while the thin LLTO film also exhibited a flexural strength of 264 MPa. The all solid-state LMBs with LFP cathode demonstrated a high initial discharge capacity of 145 mA h g−1 and a high capacity retention ratio of 86.2% after 50 cycles [280]. Except for LLTO, garnet-type LLZO has also attracted wide attention due to its high electrochemical and atmospheric stability, while it has high Li+ conductivity. Similar to sulfide solid electrolytes, the cubic LLZO is relatively stable in air and shows high ionic conductivity and good stability against Li metal anode. To obtain highly conducting LLZO, the priority is to stabilize its cubic phase [281–285]. For this purpose, Guo Group developed a W-doped LLZO ceramic electrolyte for solid state LMBs [286]. The incorporation of W proves beneficial to stabilization of cubic phase and densification of the ceramic, resulting in relative density of 96% and ionic conductivity of 6.6 × 10−4 S cm−1. Thus, the full cells with NCM333 cathode exhibited a high initial specific discharge capacity of 142 mA h g−1 at the current density of 15 mA g−1 and a high capacity retention ratio of 94% after 20 cycles. Besides, M. Laine Group overcame processing difficulties involved in LLZO cubic phase by reactive sintering carbonate and oxide nanoparticle mixtures and wet processing to minimize agglomerate formation [287]. By controlling the processing variables, 10–15 grains thick, dense (94 ± 1%) LLZO cubic phase thin (< 30 mm), flexible films with high ambient ionic conductivities (0.2 ± 0.03 mS cm−1) can be achieved using conventional casting–sintering of flame made nanoparticles (Fig. 18d). Recently, Guo et al. also reported an impressive work, in which they designed a thin asymmetric SSE to suppress the growth of Li dendrites ( Fig. 19a) [288]. In this architecture, a dense LLZO layer modified with 7.5 nm polymer is toward Li metal to prevent Li dendrite penetration. Thus, the symmetric cells maintained a flat plating/stripping voltage profile over 3200 h, thereby improving the cycling stability and safety of LMBs. Similarly, other inorganic solid electrolytes could also suppress the dendritic penetration efficiently because of its high mechanical strength [289–293].

Different from inorganic solid electrolyte, polymer electrolyte has good flexibility and elasticity, which can adapt volume change of Li metal anode during repeated charging/discharging process [294–298]. Generally, solid polymer electrolytes are comprised of polymer matrix and Li salt. The polymers must contain Lewis-base sites to solvate Li salt, and Li+ transports via hopping from one site to another. Based on such a Li+ transports mechanism, polyoxyethylene (PEO) is the most widely studied polymer matrix, but its low Li+ conductivity at room temperature hinders its practical application [299–301]. Therefore, various strategies have been explored to improve Li+ conductivity in PEO-based solid polymer electrolyte. It is wide accepted that increasing Li+ conductivity of polymer electrolyte can be achieved by lowering the glass transition temperature (Tg) of polymer [302–305]. Dispersing nanoparticles into polymer can effectively lower its Tg. For example, our Group reported a composite SiO2 polymer solid electrolyte [306]. The ionic conductivity can be improved to 5.0 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 25 °C and 90% long cycling retention is achieved.

Besides, blending with other amorphous polymer is a quite convenient way to decrease Tg. Wu et al. blended PEO with polymethylhydrogen-siloxane (PMHS) and the composite polymer electrolyte exhibited excellent ionic conductivity (2.2 × 10−2 S cm−1 at 80 °C), large electrochemical windows (5.2 V), a high degree of flexibility and thermal stability. Thus, the all-solid-state batteries with LFP cathode delivered a high capacity of 140 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C at 60 °C [307]. Cross-linking between different polymer chains is also an effective strategy in molecular level to improve the mechanical strength and Li+ conductivity of polymer electrolyte [308–312]. Guo et al. proposed an in-situ plasticized polymer electrolyte with double-network [313]. As shown in Fig. 19b, by optimizing the chain length of liquid polymer monomers, a series of improved electrochemical properties can be achieved, such as Li+ conductivity (from 10−5 to 10−4.5 S cm−1), thermal stability (up to 200 °C) and mechanical strength, thereby suppressing the growth of Li dendrites efficiently. With this polymer electrolyte, the full cells displayed a high specific discharge capacity (162 mA h g−1) and CE (> 99.5%). Besides, they also reported a bifunctional solid polymer electrolyte with interpenetrating network of poly(ether–acrylate) to suppress dendritic growth and improve electrochemical performance [314]. As shown in Fig. 19c, a unique polymer electrolyte with rigid–flexible structure can be obtained via photopolymerization of PEO and branched acrylate. Owing to the ideal combination of plasticity and rigidity, such a solid polymer electrolyte exhibited a high Li+ conductivity of 0.22 mS cm−1 and mechanical strength (~ 12 GPa), thus promoting uniform Li plating/stripping and suppressing dendritic penetration efficiently. The full cells assembled with LiFePO4 cathode exhibited a high capacity retention after 200 cycles at 1.0 C.

In brief, organic solid polymer electrolyte has high thermal and chemical stability, good mechanical properties and low-cost. However, its Li+ conductivity must be improved before practical application. Rational molecular design can solve this problem effectively. By changing the molecular structure of polymers to form various polymers with different topological structures, such as: random copolymer, segmented copolymer, graft polymer, cross-linking, hyperbranched, etc., the crystallinity can be suppressed and Li+ conductivity can be improved. By molecular design, the electrochemical properties, mechanical properties and thermal properties of polymer electrolytes can be controlled by introducing different polymer chains and controlling their molecular weight into the polymer electrolytes. However, changing the polymer structure usually means more complicated synthesis and preparation process, higher cost, lower yield.

There was another impressive work reported by Bouchet et al., in which they designed a single-ion conductive polymer electrolyte by grafting a polyanionic block copolymer with TFSI groups on PEO chains, as shown in Fig. 19d. This structure enabled an important delocalization of the negative charge, leading to a crazy high Li+ transference number (0.85) and enhanced Li+ conductivity (1.3 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 60 °C). Besides, this polymer electrolyte also exhibited excellent mechanical properties and wide electrochemical window (5.0 V vs Li+/Li). Thus, the full cells with LiFePO4 cathode showed a high specific discharge capacity and rate performance [315]. Recently, our Group proposed a thiol-branched solid polymer electrolyte, which is fabricated by covalently cross-linking metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), tetrakis (3-mercaptopropionic acid) pentaerythritol (PETMP), and poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) via multiple C‒S‒C bonds (Fig. 19e). The strong C-S-C bonds ensured excellent mechanical properties, thus overcame the trade-oﬀ between the mechanical strength and ionic conductivity, which was typical for polymer electrolytes [316].

As outlined above, there are various organic and inorganic solid electrolytes, each with its own strengths and weaknesses. Therefore, composite solid-state electrolytes have also been proposed to make best use of their advantages and bypass their disadvantages simultaneously, thereby suppressing dendritic growth and improving Li+ conductivity [317–320]. Fan Group reported a 3D fiber-network-reinforced bicontinuous solid composite electrolyte with flexible Li+-conductive network (LATP/PAN), which was shown in Fig. 19f. Because of the high mechanical strength and enhanced interfacial stability, the Li dendrites can be inhibited efficiently, thus ensuring the full cells with LiFePO4 cathode can exhibit near 100% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 0.2 C [321]. Besides, Hu Group also reported a composite solid-state electrolyte based on LLZO nanofibers, as shown in Fig. 19g. The Li salt–PEO polymer is filled into the porous LLZO networks, forming the composite electrolyte. The interwelded 3D structure constructed by LLZO nanofibers provides long-range Li+ transfer pathways and structural reinforcement to enhance the matrix of composite solid-state electrolyte. Thus, the composite solid-state electrolyte exhibited a high Li+ conductivity of 2.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 and enhanced mechanical strength, thereby suppressing the growth of Li dendrites and improving cycling stability. The symmetric cells can run stably over 300 h at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 [322]. Talking about the composite of PEO-based polymer electrolyte with LLZO ceramic electrolyte, Passerini et al. also demonstrated a hybrid ceramic-polymer electrolyte, which consists of 70 wt% of Li+ conducting LLZO and 30 wt% of P(EO)15LiTFSI polymer electrolyte [323]. As shown in Fig. 20a, compared to the stiff and fragile ceramic electrolyte, the composite electrolyte has the considerable advantage to enable a wide variety of cell shapes without cracking upon mechanical stress. Recently, our Group also proposed an asymmetric solid electrolyte based on the strategy of combining PEO with LLZO, which was shown in Fig. 20b. In this design, a soft organic–inorganic composite PEO–LLZO electrolyte is coated on one side of a separator, which is towards the cathode material to ensure as high interfacial compatibility as possible. The composite electrolyte showed a high Li+ conductivity of 3.8 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature. Benefiting from those advantages, the Li | Li symmetric cell maintains a stable Li plating/stripping process over 1600 h and full cells with LFP cathode also show stable cycling performances at 1.0 C over 200 cycles with 99.5% CE [324].

In addition to combine with ceramic LLZO electrolyte, there are also a lot of reports focusing on the composite with sulfide solid electrolyte [325]. Yang et al. designed a PEO-Li10SnP2S12 (LSPS) inorganic polymer composite electrolyte for all-solid-state Li–S batteries for the first time [326]. As shown in Fig. 20c, with adding 1% Li10SnP2S12, the as-prepared electrolyte exhibited enhanced ionic conductivity and mechanical properties, meantime, the all-solid-state Li–S battery also delivered a high specific capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 with a high CE (close to 100%) and good cycling stability at 60 °C. Besides, Ci Group also reported a hybrid solid electrolyte with Li7P3S11 being wrapped with polyethylene oxide-LiClO4 (PEO-LiClO4), which was shown in Fig. 20d. This hybrid electrolyte with a different mass ratio of LPS and PEO-LiClO4 was in-situ prepared with a facile and straight forward strategy, in which PEO-LiClO4 was served as conductive bridge between the LPS particles, thereby facilitating Li+ diffusion and decreasing the interfacial resistance. Thus, the all-solid-state Li–S batteries with this hybrid electrolyte exhibited high specific discharge capacity and improved cycling stability [327]. Furthermore, considering the “shuttle effect” in Li–S cells, Wen Group designed a composite solid electrolyte layer on Li metal anode by a spontaneous and rapid reaction between Li metal and the mixture solution of P2S5 and S in THF [328]. As shown in Fig. 20e, the main components of the protective layer are the Li3PS4 and its derivatives, which effectively stabilize the interphase of Li metal anode and suppress the shuttle effect in the Li–S batteries, enabling the greatly enhanced cycling stability and CE. Hence, with the composite solid electrolyte layer, the Li–S cells delivered a high specific capacity of 840 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.3 C with average CE of 90.1%.

Although the inorganic solid-state electrolyte can effectively suppress the growth and penetration of Li dendrites due to its high mechanical strength, high interfacial resistance between electrolyte and electrode materials seriously restricts its practical application [329–333]. It is helpful to reduce interfacial resistance by designing a transition layer which can be tightly contact with Li metal and solid-state electrolyte [334–337]. Hu et al. proposed to coat a lithiophilic materials on solid-state electrolyte to decrease interfacial resistance by ALD method, such as: Al2O3, Si, ZnO et al. [336]. After introducing a thin Al2O3 coating on Li7La2.75Ca0.25Zr1.75Nb0.25O12 (LLCZN) surface, the interfacial impedance demonstrated a significant decrease (from 1710 to 1 Ω cm−2) at room temperature ( Fig. 21a). In the meantime, they also proposed a possible mechanism based on their experimental and computational results: the Al2O3 coating enables a conformal interface of LLCZN/Li, the high binding energy of Al2O3 with Li further enhances the conformal interface; the ultrathin Al2O3 coating layer provides fast Li+ transport paths; the Al2O3 coating layer might prevent LLCZN decomposition and maintain the interface stability. Thus, the full cells exhibited a high rate capacity and cycling stability. Their Group also deposited an amorphous Si layer to decrease the interfacial resistance by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition method [338]. As shown in Fig. 21b, after coating a thin Si layer on garnet, the LixSiy formed in situ can transfer Li+ effectively between Li metal/garnet. They also confirmed the stability of interphase layer in theory. Thus, the wettability of garnet-based SSE dramatically changed from superlithiophobic to superlithiophilic behavior, reducing the interfacial resistance greatly (from 925 to 127 Ω cm−2).

LiPON has been confirmed to satisfy many critical requirements of solid electrolyte, including chemical stability, wide electrochemical window (up to 5.5 V vs Li+/Li), uniform Li+ transference number, high elastic modulus (77 GPa), indicating it can prevent the formation of Li dendrites efficiently [339–342]. Liu et al. introduced a LiPON thin film as transition layer, which was shown in Fig. 21c. The LiPON thin film displayed high mechanical property, elasticity and cycling stability, while it can form a stable contact interphase between Li anode and LAGP-based solid electrolyte. Thus, the full cells with LiFePO4 cathode can exhibit near 100% capacity retention after 150 cycles at 0.2 C [343]. Except for LiPON, traditional PEG-based polymer electrolyte can also be used to improve interfacial resistance. Yang Group coat a thin layer of PEO (LiTFSI) polymer on Li surface, which was shown in Fig. 21e. The PEO (LiTFSI) polymer layer can tightly contact with Li metal and solid-state electrolyte, thereby preventing the direct contact of LAGP from Li metal and reducing the interfacial resistance. Thus the all-solid-state cells with LiFePO4 cathode exhibited a high initial discharge capacity of 160.8 mA h g−1 and excellent rate performance at 50 °C [344].

Furthermore, the high interfacial resistance between the cathode materials and SSE is also a huge challenge [345–348]. Aiming at this issue, Wang et al. reported an interesting work, in which they introduced the Li2.3−xC0.7+xB0.3−xO3 (LCBO) interphase into to reduce the interfacial resistance between LLZO and LiCoO2. As shown in Fig. 21d, the Li2.3C0.7B0.3O3 solder can react with the Li2CO3 on the surface of LLZO and LiCoO2 during thermally soldering process, thereby forming a superior LiCoO2/LLZO interface and decreasing the interfacial resistance. Thus, the all-solid-state cells with LiCoO2 cathode delivered a large initial specific capacity, high cycling stability and excellent rate-performance at 25 °C [349].

In summary, compared with traditional liquid electrolyte, SSE can perfectly address the security issues due to its chemical stability and noninflammability. Meantime, it can suppress Li dendrite growth efficiently and improve the energy density of LMBs. However, the low Li+ conductivity and high interfacial resistance limit its practical application. It is hopefully applied practically if the Li+ conductivity can be improved to 10−4–10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature. For interfacial stability, a lot of publications have been reported to improve the interfacial compatibility between Li metal anode and SSE, but the interface between cathode and SSE is rarely considered. That is mainly because it is quite difficult to find a suitable transition layer withstanding high voltage. Besides, enhancing Li+ transference number is also helpful to improve the electrochemical performance especially rate-performance. We call for more researches on the interfacial issues and ionic conductivity, further discovering more proper SSE for LMBs.

As a “Holy Grail” anode, Li metal anode has been applied in initial rechargeable batteries. As the first generation of LIBs, it has ultra-high energy density and power density. However, the Li metal anode was abandoned in subsequent battery development for the sake of safety properties. At the moment, the commercial LIBs based on graphite anodes and lithium transition metal oxide cathodes are reaching their limits in energy density (250 W h kg−1), which can hardly meet the increasing requirements for high energy density. In this background, developing advanced electrode materials or novel battery chemistry and using Li metal anode are urgently required. If using metal Li as anode, the energy density can be improved to 440 W h kg−1. Simultaneously, the novel battery systems based on Li metal anode, such as Li–S, Li–air batteries, the energy density even can achieve 700 W h kg−1. In the past 40 years, several mechanisms have been proposed to explain the Li+ nucleation and dendrite growth. Based on these theoretical models of Li+ nucleation and growth, various approaches have been explored to regulate Li deposition and suppress Li dendrite growth. Although we have achieved great success to this day, we still face great challenges. In this section, we discuss the existing challenges and future opportunities of Li metal anode from the electrolyte point of view ( Fig. 22). Our goal is to provide the readers with critical and in-depth evaluation of the current progress and future possibilities of advanced electrolyte in Li metal anode. We summarize these electrolyte designs as follows: 1) liquid electrolyte designs; 2) ionic liquid electrolyte designs; 3) gel electrolyte designs; 4) solid-state electrolytes, etc.

Before applying in the practical batteries, there are a lot of technical or cost problems in electrolyte designs. How to optimize these designs and integrate them into safe practical battery system, it does not seem to be a simple “A + B = C” format. The selection of appropriate Li salts, solvents, additives, diluents, even packing means have a significant impact on the final electrochemical performance and safety properties of the actual LIBs. All of these aspects are worth considering in the design of high efficient electrolytes.

But anyway, whether from theoretical or experimental researches, electrolyte has a very large research space. For instance, the current proposed models based on liquid electrolyte can only describe Li deposition and growth under specific conditions, even most theoretical calculations can only simulate the behavior of a single Li+. It is necessary to establish a more comprehensive mechanism to replace these current rough models for understanding whole process of Li dendrite growth. Furthermore, the current experimental researches are mostly focusing on coin cells at a low surface current density, low cathode materials loading, high Li anode loading and low lithium utilization, etc. However, from the perspective of practical application, it is very essential to test the effectiveness of electrolyte designs in pouch cells, because the distribution of current density completely different between coin and pouch cells, and the reaction degree between liquid electrolyte and Li metal is also more intense in pouch cells. Hence, although considerable breakthroughs have been achieved, this burgeoning field of electrolyte designs is still a big challenge. There are many issues need to be considered in depth:
1.
SEI: Organic ester-based or ether-based electrolyte is the most common electrolyte for the Li metal anode, which can react easily with Li metal to form an unstable SEI layer on the Li metal surface. However, until now, we haven't got a clear understanding of the formation mechanism, structure and component of SEI layer. It is widely accepted that the higher content of F element, the more stable the SEI layer. We call for more researches on the understanding and detecting the formation progress of SEI layer, thereby laying a theoretical foundation for constructing a stable SEI layer with rapid Li+ migration by designing electrolyte composition.
2.
Organic electrolyte and Li salts: As a key part of battery, the properties of electrolyte are closely related to the electrochemical performance of LMBs. By designing solvent and Li salts in molecular level, the electrolyte system can be optimized and tailored for specific purposes. For the moment, fluorinated solvent exhibits very different physical properties (such as: noninflammability) and could be used in high-voltage LMBs. Actually, a few groups have reported some advanced electrolyte design in fluorinated electrolytes, even all-fluorinated electrolytes. However, a rational degree of fluorination should be chosen carefully according to the structure of solvent. In selecting Li salts, the LiPF6 and LiTFSI are widely used in commercial electrolyte systems. However, in high-concentrated electrolyte, the LiFSI is widely used because of its high solubility, while the electrochemical stability of LiFSI limits its applications in high-voltage LMBs. Thus, rational structure design is also important for Li salt to improve its electrochemical stability and solubility. For high-concentrated electrolyte, although high-concentrated electrolyte can effectively inhibit the dendritic growth and improve the safety of LMBs, the poor wettability and high cost limit its further application. Recently, the concept of local high-concentrated electrolyte has been proposed, but more diluting solvents need to be found to promote the efficient development of this field. For electrolyte additives, maybe it is one the most enabling strategies towards the practical application of LMBs. Up to now, a lot of additives have been reported, mainly including: SEI-forming additives and electroplating additives. However, SEI-forming additive is continuously consumed as a part of the SEI films along with the repeated Li plating/stripping process, means: it can hardly suppress dendritic growth during prolonged cycling. By contrast, although some electroplating additives are not consumed during charging-discharging process, most of them are S-containing molecules, means: if using them in high-energy-density Li–S cell, they are easy to react with S cathode or polysulfide during charging-discharging process. Hence, looking for highly effective electrolyte additives is still urgently desired for the practical applications of LMBs.
3.
Synergistic effect of additives: When two kinds of electrolyte additives with different functions are used together, what is the mechanism of synergistic effect? Is it possible to cause “1 + 1 < 2” phenomenon in electrochemical Li deposition process? These need to be further explored.
4.
Non-flammable electrolyte: Recently, some novel non-flammable electrolytes have been proposed to improve the safety of LMBs. However, they are based on phosphate solvents or perfluorinated solvents. Considering the actual production, phosphate solvents will cause serious environmental pollution, and the synthesis routes of perfluorinated solvents are complex, ineffective and high cost. Meantime, the solubility of Li salts in perfluorinated solvents is very low, which reduces the Li+ conductivity of fluorinated electrolyte. Of course, high-concentrated electrolyte also exhibits a high noninflammability. However, poor wetting capability and high viscosity hinder its practical applications. Considering the electrochemical window can be increased in high-concentrated electrolyte, maybe some high donor solvents with low viscosity can be used as solvents to dissolve Li salts, such as: 1,3-Dimethyl-Tetrahydropyrimidin-2(1H)-one (DMPU), 1,3-Dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone (DMI), 1,4-Butyrolactone, etc. Besides, using flame retardant additives is a better choice towards the practical application. Therefore, the further development of nonflammable electrolyte still needs a lot of researches to consider these properties of solvents, such as: Li+ conductivity, solubility of Li salts, environmental protection, cost, etc.
5.
Coulombic efficiency (CE): Coulomb efficiency is another noticeable problem during the cycling process of Li metal anode. Till now, a high CE of > 99.5% at high current density (5–10 mA cm−2) has not been reported. It means that the capacity of Li metal anode is at least lost 0.5% after one Li plating/stripping cycle. If the energy density of a Li–S cell is fixed at 400 W h kg−1, the area capacity of Li metal is estimated as 10–20 mA h cm−2 (excess 100%), and the corresponding thickness should be 50–100 µm. After a simple calculation, the capacity of Li metal anode can only maintain 36.7% and 0.665% of the initial Li capacity after 200 and 1000 cycles, respectively, means: even if the problems of dendritic growth and “dead Li” are not considered, the capacity retention rate of Li metal after 200 cycles is < 50%. Therefore, it is very important to improve the CE in further researches.
6.
The amount of electrolyte: For LMBs, especially Li–S cells, the amount of electrolyte is closely related to the energy density and electrochemical performance. In Li–S cells, if too much electrolyte is used, the capacity of Li–S cells will decrease sharply because of polysulfide dissolution, sulfur dissolution and shuttle effect. In current works, the amount of electrolyte is ~ 10 g/A h in Li–S cells, which is much higher than that in the actual battery (< 3 g/A h). However, if using composite Li metal anode, its high specific surface area will require more electrolyte, thereby causing more SEI formation and electrolyte consumption. Therefore, when using composite Li metal anode, the balance between the amount of electrolyte and high specific surface area of composite electrode needs to be considered.
7.
Solid-state electrolyte: Although using solid-state electrolyte instead of liquid electrolyte can effectively suppress dendritic growth and improve the safety of LMBs, the low ionic conductivity, poor interface compatibility and high cost, render a long way from practical application. For now, more and more researchers have been committed to develop solid polymer electrolytes with low cost, expandability, and good processability. However, currently polymer electrolytes still suﬀer from issues including low ionic conductivity, unsatisfactory mechanical properties, and poor interfacial compatibility at the cathode side. Thus, rational molecular designs are necessary to control the electrochemical properties, mechanical properties and thermal properties of polymer electrolytes, such as: introducing different polymer chains and controlling their molecular weight into the polymer electrolytes.
8.
Low temperature performance: According to a literature report, Li dendrites’ growth is more serious at low temperature, which leads to a poor electrochemical performance. How to effectively suppress dendritic formation/growth and improve the electrochemical performance at low temperature also need further researches. Besides, some liquid electrolytes will solidify into a solid at low temperature, which limits their effectiveness. Although ionic electrolytes have lower freezing point, the high-cost makes them hard to expand widely, not to mention the solid-state electrolytes. Thus, how to improve the low temperature performance of Li metal anode via electrolyte designs is an important research direction in the future.
9.
Rate performance: Cycling stability at high C-rates is critical and remains a great challenge for Li metal batteries. However, previous LMBs still limit their effectiveness in high current densities (> 10 mA cm−2). It is well known that ionic conductivity of electrolytes is closely related to rate performance of batteries. This is particularly important for solid-state electrolytes. But for now, the high-concentrated electrolytes and solid-state electrolytes are hard to satisfy the requirement in high rate performance. We call for more attentions on improving the ionic conductivity and suppressing dendritic growth, as well as improving the electrochemical performance of LMBs in future electrolyte designs.
10.
Gas generation: For coin cell, there is little danger because of its rigid shell structure and low gas production. However, in actual pouch cell, the battery is encapsulated in the shell of aluminum-plastic film, and gas production is very much during charging-discharging process, which will lead to safety hazards, such as: thermal runaway, fire, and even explosion. Although the influence of gas generation can be partly eliminated by battery formation, the period of battery formation is very long, which leads to a low efficiency in actual production. Therefore, it is necessary to develop more efficient electrolytes to eliminate gas generation.

Every coin has two sides. All in all, despite the Li metal anode has made great process in recent years, it is impossible to replace conventional Li-ions batteries based on graphite anode in a short time mainly because of (i) safety risks from Li metal (ii) serious Li dendrite growth and low coulombic efficiency and (iii) lack of advanced electrolytes. Only from the electrolyte perspective, in future work, researchers should focus on attaining stable SEI layer, controlling dendritic growth, decreasing “dead Li”, improving ionic conductivity and so on.

In summary, we have reviewed the progress of electrolyte to show its importance in meeting the demand of high-energy-density Li metal batteries. We do not intend to cover all existing cases related to this field, but provide typical examples that reflect the merits and trends of various electrolytes design in certain aspects. Up to now, although there are many breakthroughs on electrolyte designs from liquid to solid, still there is not a perfect solution to break through several key technical bottlenecks at the same time. We critically evaluated existing challenges and future opportunities in this review. We aim to provide a strategic guidance for the rational design and fabrication of advanced electrolyte. Through the further electrolyte researches into the science and engineering, Li metal anode will lead to a bright future with infinite possibilities toward future power market.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Qian Wang received his bachelor degree on College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, Wuhan University in 2016. He is now pursuing his Ph.D. degree at College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Peking University, Beijing, China. His research focuses on designing novel anode materials and advanced electrolytes for next generation Li-ion batteries.

Hangchao Wang obtained his Master degree at Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China. The postgraduate period, he was focused on designing and synthesizing novel solid polymer electrolytes.

Jianyang Wu received his bachelor degree in Chemistry from Xiamen University in 2019. He is currently a Ph.D. student in College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering at Peking University under the guidance of Prof, Henghui Zhou. Now he is focusing on electrolyte designs for stable Li metal batteries.

Dr. Mingyue Zhou received his bachelor degree on Material Chemistry from Nanjing University in 2015 and Ph.D. degree from National University of Singapore in 2020. He is currently a postdoctoral researcher in Tsinghua University. His present research interests including interfacial chemistry of functional materials/electrolyte and applications in electrochemical energy storage devices such as metal batteries and redox flow batteries.

Wen Liu received his Ph.D. degree on Chemistry from Peking University in 2013. After Postdoc research in Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology in Korea and Yale University in America, he is a Professor in the College of Science, Beijing University of Chemical Technology. His research interests include rational design and synthesis of nanomaterials with tunable composition, microstructure and surface chemistry, and find their application in energy storage and conversion devices such as lithium ion batteries, Li–S battery, Metal-Air battery and Water electrolysis.

Henghui Zhou received his Ph.D. degree on Chemistry from Peking University in 1998. He is presently an Associated Professor in College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Peking University and the Director of Beijing Engineering Research Center of Power Lithium-ion Battery. His research interests include design and synthesis of novel materials for energy storage and conversion, study of interface between electrode and electrolyte in chemical power source, and design and application of mobile energy devices for 3C electronics and vehicles.
